Suffering from a severe deficiency of wonder, this Alice is by turns loud, lifeless and lacklustre, and so what should have been the perfect marriage of moviemaker and material instead does justice to neither.

One can't help but feel that the Disney-Depp partnership has taken the series as far as it can go in this form, and short of a large-scale overhaul of the franchise, it may be best to set these particular Pirates adrift for good.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This tale has been told so many times that it demands a spark of invention or originality to spice things up, but Cemetery Junction sticks slavishly to story conventions, with nothing new or imaginative to say about the subject.

It's with a heavy heart that we say good-bye to Harry Potter, but in crafting what may well be the best blockbuster of the season, the boy wizard has gone out with a suitably spellbinding bang, and one that will leave a lasting impression on cinemagoers.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: While it may not be time for McClane to hang up his vest just yet, the formula is starting to seem tired, and it feels like the end might be approaching for this particular franchise.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: While this may not be the perfect Tintin adaptation, it's nevertheless an entertaining one; a film that honours the charm and spirit of the books, and one that should please fans and newcomers alike.
Goon is a surprise on pretty much all fronts, following the story beats you'd expect of a film of this genre, yet delivering them in an enjoyably unusual and offbeat manner.
A smart and immensely entertaining comedy that announces the somewhat surprising arrival of a serious comic talent in the shape of Channing Tatum.
While Sinister is hardly a game-changer, it is an extremely effective horror feature; one that creates its own highly original mythology, and wholeheartedly terrifies from start-to-finish.
Indie Game provides a gripping and consistently entertaining insight into this unique sub-set of the games industry.
The film does deliver on scares, and at a time when so few Hollywood horrors succeed on that front, we should grateful for the consistency of the Paranormal Activity films.
Silent Hill Revelation 3D is an inferior sequel in every way, shape and form, a horror sequel that fails to either intrigue or scare, and one that just might have killed the franchise cold-dead.
The Red Dawn remake has sat on the shelf for two years, and maybe it should have stayed there.
An entertaining Universal Soldier movie that dares to try something different.

When it works, however, it's a gripping thrill-ride that also serves as a timely reminder of the unique talents of Don Coscarelli, one of our most interesting filmmakers, and one who can't be allowed to go another 10 years between features.
While it doesn't exactly reinvent the wheel, this new take on the Evil Dead is every bit as good as Sam Raimi's originals, and praise doesn't get much higher than that.
While a noble effort in terms of scale and ambition, Oblivion entertains only sporadically. There's a great film somewhere in there, but this isn't it.
[The film] expertly melds action, comedy and drama to become the finest Iron Man movie yet.
It feels about 2012 minutes too long, a bloated epic that outstays its welcome long before the credits have rolled.
While it lacks the narrative cohesion of its predecessors, it surpasses them in terms of tension and scares.
Dahl aficionados will be disappointed at the Americanisation of it all, while Anderson fans will doubtless grow tired of the predictable nature of proceedings.
Neill Blomkamp's sophmore effort proves that District 9 was no fluke, with Elysium the kind of exciting and intelligent entertainment that's been sorely missing from the summer movie season.
In spite of many misgivings, including ropey CGI, convoluted storytelling and a smattering of horribly over-the-top performances, G.I. Joe is a blast from start-to-finish.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Although this is an inspirational genre pic that pushes all the requisite buttons throughout, you canâ(TM)t help but feel that rather than benching the team, director Thomas Carter should have benched a few of those ham-fisted sporting clichÃ (C)s instead.
A powerful piece, 3 Needles ultimately fails to cohere as narrative, but there can be few more compassionate films playing at the festival this year.
A rather pointless exercise that reinforces the age-old adage 'If it ain't broke, don't remake it'.
An entertaining documentary that won't change the world, but should leave you spellbound for 90 minutes.
movie_title: Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos (2006)

movie_review_blurb: While the film is rude and raucous throughout, it doesn't have a bad bone in its body, providing a joyous, celebratory swansong for the beloved characters.
Oppressive, mean-spirited and sadistic, The Beginning is an unsavoury exercise in cruelty and pain that one hopes will also be the end.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This is expertly crafted entertainment that follows all the beats of a traditional romantic comedy, but it's done with such sincerity that it's difficult to begrudge the odd descent into cliché.
Heart-warming, thought-provoking and beautifully played, it that tackles a serious subject with sensitivity and grace while providing more than a few laughs along the way.
The most unusual and original horror film to be made on these isles in many a year.
A confusing mess of a movie that lacks the marvellously sharp structure and cohesion of his previous efforts.
movie_title: I'm a Cyborg, But That's OK (Saibogujiman kwenchana) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Persepolis makes this most difficult of subjects at once watchable, accesible, and ultimately unforgettable.

Somewhere in The Happening there's a great movie struggling to break free. The concept is fantastic... but poor dialogue combined with even worse performances make for a disappointing and frustrating 90 minutes of film.
Obviously heavily influenced by the likes of Swingers and Before Sunrise, it nevertheless manages to find its own voice, combining sentiment with cynicism to create a very modern romantic comedy.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Yet because it's Smith, you know that Hancock can't be all bad, and as the film spends the next hour trying to rehabilitate him, proceedings slowly starts to fall apart.
The sub-standard work from everyone involved means that Whiteout is very much a missed opportunity that undoubtedly would have been better left on the comic book page.
A mature take on this most contentious of issues, and quite possibly the best film on the subject in 20 years.

He's hardly re-inventing the wheel with this movie, but RocknRolla is nonetheless a comedy thriller that is every bit as accomplished as his early work, and without doubt an witty, adrenalin-fuelled blast from start to finish.
Heavy Metal in Baghdad is one of those sneaky documentaries that starts out a light-hearted look at a semi-serious subject, and then suddenly turns into something far more moving and profound.

The first hour of the film has an energy and wit that makes it a joy to behold, but as Stiller tries to tie it all together into a cohesive hole, the humour drains from the piece, and it all becomes a little tiresome.

A truly uplifting 80 minutes of film, you owe it to yourselves to check out The Story of Anvil, and you then owe it to the band to buy their albums and help put them back where they belong - at the summit of mount metal.
An incredibly entertaining 95 minutes spent in the company of one of the game's most interesting characters, and a testament to the way in which friendship can save us in our darkest hour.
It's a visceral assault on the senses and will have you gasping for breath as the laughs and scares mount. Raimi directs with the confidence and flair of a genre master.

The Stath is pretty much the most bankable name in action movies today, and his unhinged work in High Voltage, indulging in an explosion of murder and mayhem with gusto and glee, should certainly see him retain that title.
An excellent creature feature. A B movie in the best sense of the word, Outlander could teach many of the so-called summer blockbusters a thing or two about character, story and performance.

A near perfect feature, a thrilling combination of humour, pathos, action and drama. Utterly original, endlessly inventive, and brilliantly crafted to appeal to old and young alike, it may well be Pixar's finest feature yet.
Given that copyright wrangles mean it may never get released, Adaptation is a covetable, Indy-worthy treasure in its own right.
movie_title: Raiders of the Lost Ark: The Adaptation (2003)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining yet uneven movie that provides comedy, drama and some interesting psychological twists and turns, but never quite delivers on that 'men on a mission' promise.
With clumsy dialogue, poor plotting and some downright terrible performances, The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus is a huge disappointment for any fan of Terry Gilliam's work.
May be the funniest film of the year thus far, but it doesn't come close to reaching the comedic heights of his previous effort, Borat.

It doesn't reach the magical heights of Alfonso Cuaron's truly spellbinding Prisoner of Azkaban, but Yates is fast approaching that territory, which bodes well for his helming of the final instalments.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's an incredible story, and in Man on Wire, Marsh has made a documentary that's worthy of his walk.
While it doesn't reach the dizzy heights of its predecessor, Kick-Ass 2 is nevertheless a hugely entertaining comic boom movie that's nastier and funnier than your average superhero flick.
If you take [Gibson's] performance on its own merits, it's one of the finest of his career; touching, terrifying and admirably understated throughout.
Machete Kills is a blast of bad taste that entertains for the majority of its run-time.
If you like your horror mixed with laughs, this anthology threequel is a blast.

The best sequence is without doubt the film's first. But the central battle is indeed spectacular, and as 'The Age of Orc' approaches, it rounds out this particular story in stirring and emotional fashion.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: While the tone is uneven and the climax something of a disappointment, The Guest is a film that succeeds thanks to the audacious efforts of its writer and director and the talents of an excellent cast.
Anchored by three dazzling central performances, it's a stunning directorial debut from Alex Garland that's essential viewing for anyone with even a passing interest in where technology is taking us.
A mildly entertaining movie that lacks the beaver bite required of such material.
Good gags, great performances and a spectacular soundtrack rescue an otherwise average coming-of-age drama.
Mr. Holmes is a moving character study that manages to find something new to say about this most enduring and beloved character.
Minions starts strong but quickly runs out of steam.
Ultimately there are enough good jokes to make the feature a worthwhile endeavour.
The result is a film that's as good as its predecessors, and suggests that Refueled isn't the last that we'll see of this particular incarnation of the Transporter.
From Heart of Darkness to Lost in La Mancha, there have been many great documentaries about the trials and tribulations of making movies, and Raiders! deserves to takes its place alongside them.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While it looks stunning, the result is a film that largely puts spectacle before substance, with this tragic story deserving of more.
A genre mash-up that deliver on both fronts, Bone Tomahawk is a two-hour blast that features great dialogue, strong characters, and imaginative and memorable kills.
While it's a stylish feature, the film lacks true substance, with SPECTRE a solid effort but one that falls frustratingly short of greatness.
Spring is a unique, engaging and utterly beguiling feature; one that smartly defies genre conventions at every turn.
Kill Your Friends starts out an enjoyably nasty satire of the music industry, but loses focus when a thriller element is thrown into the mix.
If you can leave your social conscience at the door, and don't mind a duff plot and paper-thin characters, you'll find Grimsby to be very, very funny.
An emotional rollercoaster that will make you happy and sad and pleased that a guy like Tim McVey is out there, nibbling dots and avoiding his tail, all the while striving for his dream.
movie_title: Man vs. Snake: The Long and Twisted Tale of Nibbler (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Jason Bourne has a passable plot and a couple of pulsating sequences, which already makes it better than the majority of action movies.

Beware the Slenderman is a little long, and rarely an easy watch. But it tells an important story about the dangers of the Internet, and the potentially deadly consequences that exposing the wrong material to the wrong people can have.
The anecdotes come thick and fast in this likeable documentary about the artists who craft nightmare fuel for a living.
movie_title: Creature Designers - The Frankenstein Complex (Le complexe de Frankenstein) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Blair Witch is a terrific sequel that stays true to the spirit of the original while at the same time developing and expanding upon the legend.

Raw is as lyrical a film about cannibalism as you are ever likely to see, so ignore the hype about audience members fainting or being sick, and instead revel in the strange beauty of its twisted tale.
It isn't always successful, but when the film works, it's a blast.
Light on gore but heavy on brains, The Girl With All the Gifts delivers what it means to be living, undead or a new combination of the two, with originality and guts.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Another funny and deeply affectionate portrait of an intriguing sub-culture.
Arrival is an alien invasion movie for grown-ups; one that's lacking in action, explosions and all-out war, but heavy on tension, drama, and raw emotion.
The result is a loosely knitted together series of vignettes, some of which raise titters, but the majority of which elicit groans.
With a narrative that surprises at every turn, committed performances from all involved, and a sense of humour as dark as the horror on display, The Loved Ones is a true horror gem.

A film made by people who clearly love the genre and have skillfully taken a simple premise and infused it with laughs and scares to craft what may be the most downright entertaining horror film of the year.
A likeable family film that - much like Eddie's own exploits - is guaranteed to put a big smile on your face.
Fury is filled with great scenes that hammer home the bravery of such men, and the tragedy of their situation.
It bravely tackles a difficult subject with grace and sensitivity, and its message is deeply moving and affecting.
When it's funny, it's laugh-out-loud hilarious. So while the film has weaknesses, it's nevertheless a sequel that actually improves on the original.
movie_title: Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead (Død snø 2) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A fun flick about table-top gaming culture and the challenges of being a geek in the modern age.
Housebound is a horror-comedy that ticks practically every box required of both genres and throws in a few extra for good measure.
The result is a thought-provoking flick that's smarter than the average blockbuster, but one that never quite fulfills the potential of the book on which it is based.
The result is a good Thor movie when post-Avengers we wanted a great one.
One of the best looking and sounding films of the year on top of being one of the most exciting.
This hugely entertaining account of Doctor Who's beginnings should appeal to casual and hardcore fans alike.
movie_title: An Adventure in Space and Time (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Entertaining, frustrating and annoying in equal measure.
Simple, effective and consistently provocative, Cheap Thrills is a masterful debut from a director to watch.
The best movie that Alfred Hitchcock never made, Grand Piano is a wild ride that features several enjoyably silly twists and turns and a grandstanding central performance from Elijah Wood.

While Padilha and his team are to be admired for bringing the concept up-to-date and addressing concerns about drones [etc.]... they've taken much of the fun out of the concept, making for a po-faced and ultimately somewhat forgettable Robocop movie.

While Jarmusch's vision is an original take on the genre, it's also hard to fully engage with his efforts, the pace too stately, the script too self-conscious, and the initially intriguing characters ultimately outstaying their welcome.
Rise of an Empire is a sumptuous feast for the eyes that's a worthy sequel to the action classic that doesn't improve on the formula, but does entertain for the majority of its run-time.

[It] feels like Wes Anderson's most heartfelt film thus far. One that effortlessly straddles genres and works as both a nostalgic paean to a more innocent time and an examination of the very nature of storytelling itself.

In refusing to spoon-feed the audience information, Glazer's film instead burrows into the brain, the ambiguous nature of proceedings making it all-the-more beguiling. The result is a film that's hard to shake after the credits have rolled.

If you're willing to go with that - an affectionate character study of a bloke in a massive papier mache head - you'll find Frank to be a richly rewarding film, and the title character to be one you can't help but fall in love with.
If you aren't squeamish, Filth is a marvelously messed up festive flick that manages to be shocking, hilarious and ultimately quite poignant.
Powerful and intelligent filmmaking that demands to be seen.
The quality is higher this time around, meaning that ABCs 2 featuring many more hits than misses.
If you can suspend your disbelief and embrace the somewhat silly concept, there's fun to be had watching Daniel Radcliffe dance with the devil.
Electric Boogaloo is a superficial examination of the Cannon story, but a hugely entertaining one.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Predestination has a few flaws in terms of story and structure, but for the most part it's a challenging and frequently thrilling time-travel yarn that will have you scratching you head for days.
The universe that that's set up is an intriguing one. The mission that Wick embarks on a compelling one. And in terms of action, drama and excitement, the film truly delivers.
A thought-provoking and strangely hilarious feature that blends elements of drama and horror with the blackest of comedy, Nightcrawler is a film that truly gets under the skin.

This sequel features at least as many shocks and laughs as its predecessor, all wrapped in a cinematic sheen that sets it apart from what's gone before, and suggesting that there might be life in the Inbetweeners yet.
If you liked 21 Jump Street, you'll like 22 Jump Street, because it's pretty much the same movie.
Thanks to brisk direction from Doug Liman and some clever plotting, said repetition never becomes predictable.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A film that's as funny as it is silly, twisting every cliché in the rom-com cannon to impressive effect, so much so that you'll never be able to look at a Katherine Heigl movie in the same way again.
Nymphomaniac is brave, thought-provoking filmmaking from a genuine auteur.
The film works as an entertaining rumination on man's relationship with technology and increasing reliance on machines.
Its star delivers a note-perfect performance that saves the film from its own shortcomings, with Tom Hardy once again proving himself to be one of the finest actors of his generation.
They are enjoyable moments in a film that entertains for much of its run-time, and it's still a blast watching these '80s icons get together to blow stuff up onscreen.
As usual with Swanberg's films, the performances are both natural and dynamic, validating his improvisational approach.
[Boyhood] plays like a lyrical series of snapshots, capturing the kind of shared moments in time that seem to resurface almost randomly in our memories.
It's difficult to invest in a character willing to risk his job for such low stakes, especially a father ... The D Train loses steam as it wavers between subversive and inevitable
A thrilling work of sci-fi ... a smart and visually alluring film that contemplates chilling questions about where technology is headed and the consequences of playing God.

Deathly Hallows -- Part 2 lives up to the standard set by its predecessors, remaining true to their spirit while also delivering an epic battle royal between Harry (Daniel Radcliffe) and Lord Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes).
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Vol. 2 concludes the tale, but it heads to the finish line with a casual stroll, not a sprint.
An epic of intimate objectivity.
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Mr. Caviezel's naturalness provides this movie's artistic salvation.
This is the kind of faux-dignified freak show that was once the stuff of parody and satire. Now it pats itself on the back for being 'risqué' and treats itself seriously.
The lessons offered by Spring, Summer are as old as time. And for those who choose to worship at the altar of cinema, the images are unforgettable.
The acting is solid, but the tone is grating.
A thriller of conviction, class and deceptive simplicity.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Broken Wings tells the kind of story that only a cinematic neophyte would find novel. But it tells that story with such emotional nuance, and with such fine performances, that it somehow feels fresh.
Dogville is not a masterpiece, nor is it an embarrassment. But it is a cinematic Rorschach test, as much fun to praise and to scorn as it is to watch.
Fast and goofy.
The performances range from solid to excellent (Mr. Gosling and Mr. Donovan are among the standouts), and the ubiquitous teen angst is handled with a minimum of condescension.

Does the radical choice to split up the action contribute anything that couldn't be achieved in a more traditional format? The answer is a well-earned affirmative, and the drama is solid enough to make the whole enterprise worthwhile.
Smacks of self-indulgence and misplaced ideals.
In Lost Boys of Sudan, we don't just hear about the steps of assimilation; we see them, and we feel their cumulative effect.
Despite all indications that he would make a fun drinking buddy, Ben Affleck, teen idol, Oscar-winning screenwriter, can't act his way out of a paper bag.
I emerged charmed by some characters, a bit more informed than before about Burning Man as a whole, but decidedly non-immersed.
It's giddy and groundbreaking, a feast for the head and the heart.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Might evaporate if it were any drier. But it is a comedy, and a pretty charming one at that.
The impulses to entertain and enlighten are at odds here, and the final result ends up landing somewhere in between: smart, funny, but rarely both at the same time.
This 'Why bother?' spinoff of the '70s undercover cop show is little more than a 99-minute shtickfest built around something resembling a plot.
Ambitious and uneven, visceral and pungent.
A king-size cult comedy hit.
Controversy aside, it is dramatically intense, skillfully constructed and often harrowing, in ways that should have an impact on people of any or no particular faith.
A white-knuckle adventure that combines the suspense of great drama with the veracity of documentary.
The leisurely pace and fatalism become riveting, and the film takes on an unnerving, unblinking intimacy, even as the characters remain distant.
You'll be swept away by sights that you'll never be able to see on The Weather Channel.
It's an impressively unified vision, with sterile set design, a wonderfully crisp and creepy sound design by Walter Murch.
It's hard to imagine that the chronicle of an artistic ordeal could be this much fun to watch.
An odd, slightly icky little film, deftly shot and self-assured but unbelievable on just about every level, emotional and otherwise.
Packs staggering levels of craft and imagination into every last frame.
Dig! strikes it rich by contrasting the stories of two bands going in different directions and the animosity that builds between them.
The Grudge shows just enough blood to be scary but not self-indulgent.
An intimate epic with the scope of old Hollywood and the emotional depth of a rigorous art film.
Profane, violent, and scabrously funny, this Team has something to offend all, from pious Hollywood liberals to knee-jerk nationalists.
This no-budget brainteaser from Dallas native Shane Carruth offers ample intellectual rewards.
A heady, messy piece of existential angst that works against all odds.
This one has the slickness of the Shrek movies, but there's not a whole lot beneath the surface.
Once you get past the sleazy residue of the borderline soft-core porn scenes, When Will I Be Loved gets into a kind of low-rent Cassavetes groove.
Little more than war porn.
The cast is, for the most part, fun, and the story addresses themes of family togetherness and humility in a way that won't make you gag.

Makes a crucial argument that has less to do with conservatives and liberals than with the coarsening of political discourse and the sinking standards of journalism and news -- subjects that go far beyond any particular news operation.
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An intricate drama that derives tragedy from emotional indifference, immaturity and fatigue, qualities that have spelled doom for more than a few marriages.
Worth a look, thanks mostly to Mr. Jane's troubled swagger and Ms. Hughes' sharp eye.
Maddening, invigorating, ridiculous, hilarious and messier than a rack of ribs without a napkin.

In those rare instances when it's not being a dumb comedy, Harold and Kumar is a rather crafty satire of racial stereotypes (which, it must be said, traffics in a few stereotypes of its own).
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: No rock doc has burrowed so deeply into the bruised egos, arrested development and internal conflict that make up a superstar band.
A tense, immediate, no-frills drama about desperate choices made under desperate circumstances, and the consequences of those choices.

Snappy and visually spry, with a treasure trove of vintage instructional and industrial film clips, this is an urgent, overlong (more than two hours) work that delivers a timely message about the times in which we live.
A haunting look at the historical amnesia that envelops countries or regimes after officially sanctioned barbarism.
movie_title: S21: The Khmer Rouge Death Machine (2004)

movie_review_blurb: If you found The Bridges of Madison County too demanding, if you like your romance with an extra helping of syrup, then your movie has arrived.
Love it or hate it, Fahrenheit is unprecedented in its relentless and up-to-the- minute attack on a sitting president.

Worth seeing, especially for anyone interested in American art history.

This is a movie that has the strength of its convictions, and it's anchored by top-shelf performances that go out on a limb time and again.

movie_review_blurb: It's a nice little movie, amateurish in some expected first-time-filmmaker ways but usually competent and never a disaster.

A delightful adventure for families.
A smart, understated, emotionally penetrating drama that tempts one to forgive Breakfast of Champions and Trixie.
A fun way to kill two hours.
A spry documentary that makes the most of two compelling characters.

A handsomely mounted Hollywood affair with a can't-miss story.

Works as a character study and a quiet thriller.

An intriguing blend of mysticism and earthiness.
Stylish, meticulous and moody, thanks largely to the work of cinematographer Henri Decae.

Wry, whimsical and sure of tone, dry in all of the right ways and without an ounce of condescension.
Exactly what it looks like: a cute premise extended to feature length, with plenty of opportunity for Mr. Carrey to mug for the camera.
The devil may come in many forms, but few have been more entertaining.
The camera work is fluid, the concept intriguing.

Burns with emotional truth.

Faithful to its source but rather unremarkable as a movie experience.
A savvy look at generation gaps and parental disappointment, and the often-wide chasm that separates pragmatism and ideology.
If the film is manipulative, at least it's subtly manipulative.

Boasts so many moments of sublime acting that it's hard to know where to start.
For enduring this mess/ They should pay us a fee.

You haven't seen this many outrageous costumes since the Halloween parade on Cedar Springs.

Even when miscast, [Hopkins and Kidman] are capable of spellbinding performances.

Slight, sweet and smart, it's a modest crowd-pleaser that doesn't make you feel like a yahoo for cheering, and it displays a mastery of tone that the big boys would do well to study.
A by-the-book, inspirational piece of Hollywood storytelling that tells you where it's headed in the first few minutes and manages to stay engaging until the end.
A feast of bravura filmmaking, thoroughly engaging and unique in even its most derivative elements.

Might make action fans pull their hair out.

An aptly named blast from the past that manages to sizzle in the present.

Michael Bay has made a movie that makes you ponder matters more meaningful than how cool that last car chase looked.
