Remarkably, the story, adapted by Blume with her son, director Lawrence Blume, seems as fresh, painful and poignant as when she wrote it.
A feature-length chunk of product placement masquerading as a comedy of teamwork and aspiration.
Stories We Tell is just the latest reminder of nonfiction film's current, endlessly innovative state. That's a story worth savoring.

Abrams' sophomore effort picks its references well, builds on the relationships established in the original series (and tweaked in the last movie) and keeps the quips and battles coming. Warp speed, Captain.
Luhrmann hasn't unlocked the secrets of a story that remains all but unfilmable, but his Gatsby is far more than a collection of superficial splashes and tics.
The movie is shrewd enough to skitter along so frenetically that nothing, not even tonal contradiction, can stick.
42 escapes the trappings of sheer hero worship largely thanks to Boseman, whose relative anonymity eliminates any potential star baggage. More than that, he strikes a tough balance.
A light-stepping kids comedy for grown-ups.
Aesthetics are steering this ghostly ship, leaving narrative in the background to fend for itself. Fortunately, Park is in full command of his repertoire.
Oz the Great and Powerful somehow manages to be both slavish to its hallowed template (when convenient) and completely tone-deaf to the magic that made it a one-of-a-kind cultural milestone.
It's all more than a little silly, but Willis' presence at least provides undercurrents of easy jocularity.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Modest in scale, it's the kind of American independent film that brings some honor to that shopworn descriptor.
Soderbergh, in what's rumored to be his final theatrical release (don't believe it), jumps from imitating the master to imitating the master imitators.
The movie has a wry sense of humor that manages to coexist with its all-you-need-is-love theme.
You can overlook an awful lot in a comedy when it makes you laugh.
If you have fond, 33-year-old memories of averting your young eyes from a propulsive parasite critter, Prometheus might just be your kind of return trip.
Woodstock, and hippie grandmas everywhere, demand better.
It's among the most understated anti-war films ever made, effortlessly humanistic but far too subtle to indulge in preaching.
Alexander Payne has been gone so long, it's easy to forget just how good he is. With The Descendants, the director's first feature since 2004's Sideways, he reminds us what we've been missing.
Within the sprawling biopic that is J. Edgar beats the heart of a love story.
Pedro Almodóvar wows with the meticulous visual design of his films, but sometimes his narrative architecture is every bit as dazzling.
Eddie Murphy reignites his inner firecracker in Tower Heist, a middling comedy caper that can't match its star's focus.
Masterful.

The very qualities that fuel the historical hokum of Anonymous -- over-the-top royal intrigue and incest, violent literary backstabbing, frothing conspiracy -- also happen to make for wild entertainment.
The movies have long been mad about the onset of madness.
Highly engaging.
Give credit to Craig Brewer, the filmmaker behind the new Footloose, for realizing a new step was in order.
How do you assess a movie when you know it's been edited down against the filmmaker's stern will? That's the dilemma created by Margaret.
The Ides of March, George Clooney's despairing political drama set against the backdrop of a bruising Ohio Democratic primary, presents us with a most unsentimental education.

Emotionally honest even when it's going for big laughs and filled with lived-in visual detail, it's raunchy and touching without ever being crude or mawkish, a small, sharp comic jewel with a big heart.
Smart, minor-key entertainment.
The first half of Drive unfolds like a romantic reverie.
[A] curiously inert new thriller from Steven Soderbergh.
The Man Who Fell to Earth today plays like a movie that fell from the sky, origins unknown.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Miranda July's second feature is beguiling, quietly funny and finally very sad in a way that sneaks up on you before becoming clear as the Los Angeles skies beneath which it's set.
There's something lived-in and genuine about this infectious melodrama.
A stripped-down sci-fi indie that made waves at the Sundance Film Festival in January.
I want to hate The Change-Up for its relentless scatology, its imaginative bankruptcy, its juvenile need to push every superficial content restriction to the outer limits.
Conjured through the ever-expanding magic of performance-capture technology, the apes are easily the most compelling elements of Apes.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Sorry, dudes. It seems we can't do anything right, but we're still funny. Sometimes.
[A] loud new action genre mash-up.
Tabloid, Errol Morris' latest wild and woolly portrait of human self-delusion, is a scandal-sheet dream come to life.
Much of the movie's success rests on the ample shoulders of Jacob Wysocki, who finds a sweet guileless spot as the title character.
No fourth wall is safe in The Muppets, and that's a great piece of news.
There are 8 million stories in this naked tragedy. Parkland is content to tell parts of some of them.
A severe and ecstatic work of art.
Ameena Matthews, Cobe Williams and Eddie Bocanegra used to instigate Chicago street violence. Now they live for nipping it in the bud, block by treacherous block.
A riot of splashy colors, silly 3-D gimmicks, big, broad kid-friendly gags - and those professionally pesky penguins.
The only one who comes out of this odd pairing unscathed is Walt Disney, looking smarter than ever for boiling the tale down to its mythical essence way back in 1937.
Given its aggressiveness in all cinematic matters, My Way manages to color in the personal stakes with enough clarity to keep you caring about the players set loose on its massive canvas.
If nothing here offends you, take a bow on behalf of your stout constitution. If nothing here makes you laugh, you might need to loosen up a tad.
Watching Bernie is a little like sitting on a shady front porch and gossiping with the town tattlers.
Whedon knows how to be self-aware without getting overly cute about it. He has fun highlighting each character's neurosis and knows which personalities clash to greatest effect.
You needn't be a fanboy to enjoy the moment when the ride really takes off and the spectacle flowers. A scary imagination will do just fine.

It speaks to anyone who's been on either end of a grudge or family antagonism. And it saves its best for those who have witnessed clusters of the best and brightest descend to the level of grade school kids on the playground.
There's no center to Mirror Mirror, no sense that anyone involved knew what exactly what they were shooting for.
Not even the outcome's predictability (hint: romantic comedies have happy endings) can dampen the frothy results.
When it's over, you'll be relieved to come up for air. You'll also be glad you took the plunge down under.
The design is witty and imaginative, and the small grace notes are enough to keep an open-minded adult giggling.
The movie doesn't pretend to be anything but propaganda, a modern-day cousin to the morale-boosting documentaries made by John Huston and Frank Capra during World War II.
A well-meaning tale of descent and redemption flatter than a Lone Star prairie.
To say the piercing Iranian film A Separation is about divorce is a bit like saying The Wizard of Oz is about a pair of slippers.
It's pretty good.
Men in drag are usually played for laughs. Women passing as men? Expect a tragic twist.
Skillfully acted by Jodie Foster, John C. Reilly, Christoph Waltz and Kate Winslet, [it's a] compact verbal slugfest.
Adepero Oduye is excellent as a Brooklyn teen coming to terms with her sexual identity in this gritty film
The Artist is charming as all get-out, a delightful little movie about the movies.
The scope and craft are dazzling.
The Adventures of Tintin can be a delight to look at, even if motion capture isn't your particular cup of animation tea.
Projects and directors are rarely better matched than The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo and David Fincher.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The literal and figurative high point of Mission: Impossible -- Ghost Protocol comes at about the halfway point, in and around the tallest building in the world in Dubai.
The comedy of discomfort, so long defined by Curb Your Enthusiasm and its ilk, gets a new hue with Young Adult.
[A] graphic and spontaneous portrait of a spiraling sex addict.
The first narrative film portrait of the white-blond cyber bad boy feels undercooked and overwrought, haphazardly written and overdirected.
The movie, based on a true story, shows how empathy has the power to destroy intolerance where it stands.
Nebraska is the work of a great director hitting his stride.
The Martian is fueled by charm, curiosity and the scientific method. It plays like a modernized Kennedy-age fantasy of discovery, space and can-do initiative.
The line between gimmicky and magic can be mighty fine, but Robert Zemeckis masters it like a seasoned pro in The Walk.
Stonewall isn't good, but it's not quite as bad as you might imagine.
The climbing sequences, which take up the bulk of the movie, pack a visceral punch.

Ultra works by making a potentially messy story rather simple, and by using its carnage as an extension of its comedy. It has no interest in piling on plot minutiae. It's too busy getting to the next bit of mayhem.
Straight Outta Compton manages to keep its sharp teeth despite its adherence to form. The movie doesn't neuter N.W.A.'s story so much as mold it to a familiar model.
It's as if it looked at possible templates for excitement and willfully decided to go for something more disjointed and boring.
Apatow and Schumer know that sturdy comedy benefits from the stuff of real life, and they supply it in consistent and sneaky fashion.
The Perfect Shot might not be the perfect movie, but it's still a worthy profile of the defining Dallas sports star of this generation.
A movie like Jurassic World must pass one basic test: Stay diverting, if not spectacularly entertaining, even through the most ridiculous scenarios. Mission accomplished.
Aloha, for all its spasms of charm, feels like a push-button romance, its heroes glibly spouting lines with the hope that the words come to mean something.

Mad Max: Fury Road provokes the same question from its audience again and again: What can you show me next? The answer is always the same: Something even more outlandish and imaginative than what you just saw.
Thomas Vinterberg's sturdy new film adaptation brings out some of the darker shades, literally and figuratively, in Hardy's proto-feminist tale.
Black Souls is above all the story of a family divided, a fraternal knot that can be untied only through tragedy.
By making the Avengers snarky rivals as well as brothers and sisters in arms, franchise Big Brain Joss Whedon injects exactly what such a noisy spectacle needs: a dollop of charm.
Clouds of Sils Maria is fiendishly wise to the ways of show business, particularly the boxes in which it places women. But the film offers more than that.

The Hunting Ground qualifies as activist filmmaking. More power to it. You can read all the statistics you want, but there's no substitute for bearing witness - especially in such overwhelming numbers.
This is big-boned, epic filmmaking of a variety Cecil B. DeMille or D.W. Griffith would appreciate.
It may not be fair to call Yann Demange a great filmmaker after just one feature, but that feature, '71, just might be a great film.
Moore delivers something remarkable here: a completely ego-free portrait of a woman who knows only ego.
The dashes of momentum are just a tease. It's hard to remember the last time this much sex was this tedious.
A lot of movies spin their wheels fast and create the illusion that important things are happening. A Most Violent Year, one of the best movies of 2014, does the opposite.
Perhaps the Sony hackers should have skipped The Interview and tried to shut down Blackhat. Then again, they never said they had anything against abject boredom.
Mr. Turner, like just about all movies made by Mike Leigh, creates the sensation of being in a vividly realized mini-universe built from the ground up.
Inherent Vice lives happily on the outer limits, where the noir form and its history are at least as important as the content.

Spectre wants to operate as both a grim post-9/11 thriller and a throwback spy yarn, and it succeeds often enough. There's something audacious about positing a massive security and civil liberties threat right in the heart of central government.
Though it never uses the term "PTSD," American Sniper, at its best, is a devastating portrait of post-traumatic stress disorder.
It's a great story about getting the story.
Creed is the happiest surprise of the movie season, a mix of old and new that taps our reservoir of nostalgia and forges a path of its own. It serves comfort food with fresh ingredients.
Few artists are so adept at addressing the past and embracing the future all at once. And few recent films have so gracefully captured a musician at a specific point in his time.
Thoroughbreds is a film of exquisite style and deceptive substance.
A densely plotted, lurid and rather satisfying spy spectacle whose greatest asset is a movie star showing us why she's a movie star.
A color-blasted head trip laden with gasp-worthy sights that also carries out the essential sci-fi mission of making us consider what it means to be human in a modern world.
Happy End will likely go down as a minor film from a major filmmaker, which is enough to make it worth your while if you can take the emotional hit.
Eastwood will be 88 in May. If I'm doing anything when I'm 88 as well he makes movies, I'll be a very happy 88-year-old.
Because of Kruger, In the Fade maintains a daunting level of emotional truth to the last.
A tense, finely observed Texas crime drama, produced on a tight budget and suggesting great promise for its Dallas-based filmmakers.
It's a piercing glimpse of a young man's bright, confounding first love, the kind of love that brings disorientation and rhapsody.
It's a finely calibrated film, brimming with romance, excitement and humanity.
It constantly keeps us off balance, even as it never loses its own.
It sends the mind moving, to the links between Vietnam and Iraq, to the bonds of grief and friendship, and to what it means to serve a country and an institution that gives and takes away.
This is an intensive appreciation of perhaps the greatest living American essayist, and one of the best ever. It plays like a finely tuned authorized biography.
movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Sacred Deer is far from a standard psycho-revenge yarn, and its serrated edge is nothing like even the nominal art films you're likely to see.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Tower manages to collapse the space between past and present, which, given the timeliness of the subject matter, has a haunting effect.
A measured but devastating movie that haunts the imagination and conscience.

Fuqua has watched his John Ford, evident in the sweeping mountain vistas that use every inch of the screen, and his Sergio Leone, represented by the squinty tension that fills the air before every showdown.
Indignation is one of those films that creates the impression of little happening, when in fact Schamus, and Roth, are pulling levers of life-and-death importance.
Writer/director Cynthia Mort tells this story well enough, but we're still left wondering why she chose this story to begin with.
Minimalist, slow to burn and utterly confident in its style and tone, Robert Eggers' Colonial New England fairy tale earns its chills the old fashioned way, through timing, atmosphere and skill.
The ravenously beautiful revenge saga from Alejandro González Iñárritu plays like the meanest Jack London short story imaginable. Its thrills chill to the bone.
Room is a good movie with a great performance at its core. Larson's career was already going places... But Room will be remembered as the movie that etched her permanent place on the map.
Put your hand in your pocket, real slow-like, and get out your wallet. You'll want to buy a ticket for The Hateful Eight, the Western that Quentin Tarantino was born to make.
Go see The Force Awakens with an open mind, and without expectations of the same lightning being captured again in the same bottle. It is, at the end of the day, a movie. And it's a pretty good one.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In the Heart of the Sea is everything you might expect and a little bit less. It's solid if rarely spectacular, engaging if rarely engrossing.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film balances action and suspense with the kind of political and military gamesmanship that would be at home in a Shakespeare history play (minus the lush language, of course).

If you're reading this article, chances are you have at least a passing interest in the role and value of newspapers. You like original reporting and writing enough to pay for it, online or on newsprint. And you'd probably enjoy Page One.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It would be hard to foul up the story of Alan Turing, and thankfully The Imitation Game doesn't.
Admirably cogent, even colloquial, Exodus plows through its stages efficiently, methodically and without much Old Testament passion.
It's so archly intellectual that you fear it might splinter if you poke it in the ribs. It's also endlessly playful in its worship of American movie tropes, and deeply resourceful.
The movie earns its keep with inspired one-off moments that showcase a mischievous sense of humor.
If you're into superlatives - and who isn't? - Godzilla conjures the most jaw-dropping giant monster sequences since the original King Kong.
Unfortunately, concise comedy gives way to desperation less that halfway through, and we're left with the spectacle of adults embracing extreme immaturity just because they can.
It's a terse, lean terror with a big, swinging tail.
Makes its targets clear: redemption, love, healing, handkerchiefs.
Charmingly glib, packed with moments that demand grace under pressure, Draft Day is prime Costner turf.
It captures the torment of one chosen as an instrument by a vengeful Old Testament God, and it breaks a story of cosmic dimensions into brutally human terms.
The constant machinations can get a little confusing. Thankfully, Boynton, a dogged reporter, manages to keep the story on a human scale.
Hey, we gotta kill time between Hunger Games installments somehow. Why not Divergent?

Playing an Old World charmer with clipped diction and a deliciously foul mouth, Fiennes, making his debut with Anderson's stock company, falls into lockstep with the filmmaker's unmistakable universe.
The new RoboCop has just about no interest in being the old RoboCop, and for that we can be thankful.
When you realize it's not coming together, your first impulse is to ask: What happened?
A fun, naughty little frolic that knows the timeless rules of break-up-to-make-up comedy.
A stinging romance for our solipsistic techie-centric times.
Every scene of 12 Years a Slave, and almost every shot, conveys some penetrating truth about America's original sin.
[Russell] seems to be having obscene amounts of fun, which becomes contagious very quickly.
When the Coen brothers commit to something, there's no half-stepping. Every street corner bristles with authenticity. Every song lands exactly where and how it should.

Beneath Banks' crass self-aggrandizement lies a pretty charming portrait of two overly proud people butting creative heads. Yes, charming. That's what Disney does, and it does it well enough to turn even this condescending pap into something palatable.
A silly sequel to the 2004 Will Ferrell breakout comedy, this new chapter manages to make some smart satirical hay in the course of its stupidity.
Go ahead. Soak up the Beauty. It's one of the best films of the year.
Peter Jackson, take a fire-breathing bow.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: We're in the steady hands of Paul Greengrass, a director fully aware that convincing crisis stories involve conflicting interests and passions.
Grimy and unapologetically melodramatic, Furnace pounds out a steady beat of pulp, violence and possible redemption among folks who have seen better days.
Powered by an infusion of gospel and hip-hop that cleverly bridges gaps between generations and values.
The movie is witty and alive and only very occasionally maudlin.
Subliminal editing, seamless flashbacks and evocative musical cues make for a captivating trek that dances off the linear path, even as it marches doggedly ahead.
The film builds its stakes with a methodical reverence for the natural world that the trio seeks to protect.
The whole thing is very smart and sweet, as are the performances.
The movie marks the first time Rock's stand-up persona - cutting, vulnerable, afraid of no sacred cows - has survived intact on the way to the multiplex. That alone is reason for fans to celebrate.
Once you accept that the splitting of Mockingjay is a business decision, not a dramatic imperative, Part 1 comes off as a curiously satisfying nonaction movie.
It nestles into your consciousness with soft lighting and inspiration.
The climax contains some tangled magic. If you're not exhausted by almost three hours of intergalactic lecturing, you may even be able to feel it.
This is icy-dry comedy, perfectly calibrated to the movie's snowy environs.
Writer-director Dan Gilroy wants it both ways - snarling comedy and gripping thriller - and for the most part he gets what he wants.

Whiplash darts along at an urgent bebop pace and asks questions applicable to most fields: How much are you willing to endure for the chance to be great? And what if cruelty isn't a better motivator than kindness?
I want to like Birdman more, but I don't have to; it's already so pleased with itself.
War is hell. It's also relentless, unsparing, unsentimental and violent to the mind, body and soul. Fury conveys these truths with brute force and lean, precise drama.

Bill Murray is one of those actors blessed with the gift of making bad behavior seem grizzled and adorable. It's a valuable tool in any funny person's kit, and Murray uses it to carry the benignly naughty St. Vincent above its material.
If the pacing sags a little, and the scale is more modest than the 60 Minutes scandal at the heart of The Insider, Kill the Messenger is still crisp, smart and gutsy.
A zesty tale of common cause that bursts at the seams with fine performances.
Gone Girl thrives on enigma, and the leads embody that quality to wonderful effect.
A strangely lethargic and self-consciously arty trudge that struggles to find a narrative through-line or turn the great Hendrix into a vivid personality.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A benign, gently naughty and rarely unpleasant dramatic comedy, the movie benefits from the kind of cast that can cover a lot of warts and keep the cookie cutter churning along.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Where comedy provides the tonic in so many films, it's the hint of reality that pushes in at the edges and changes the pace here. These guys are funny. But they know their longer trip will continue once the last plate of pasta is empty.
If only the characters didn't have to talk.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In the absence of novelty, execution becomes vital, and What If hits its marks with wit, consistency and even a bit of visual inventiveness.

It avoids the predictable narrative arc - hardscrabble youth, rise to fame, descent into drugs, etc. - by scrambling the Brown chronology and shooting for a more thematic organizing structure marked by smart transitions.
A rather sad movie about the potential futility of doing good, or at least taking the difficult path, in a complicated world.
To say Boyhood wouldn't be that special if it were shot in a conventional manner is kind of like saying that elephant in the zoo wouldn't be so big if it weren't so big.
Dawn of the Planet of the Apes wisely weaves a tale of the flaws in human and simian natures. It also manages to say a thing or two about the hollowness of most summer blockbusters.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Incisive, graceful and, yes, deeply empathetic.
Begin Again is corny, improbable and generally a great deal of fun.
It's hardly an essay on gender politics, but read between the lines and you'll find some interesting contrasts.
A foul-mouthed comedy with an immature heroine has treated a thorny issue with remarkable candor.
It's been argued that movie comedies no longer have jokes. I would go one step further. The similarly titled (and similarly sloppy) Bad Teacher and Horrible Bosses barely even have stories.
Sharp of tongue, generous of spirit, Silver Linings Playbook is a jagged, loopy romantic comedy about "crazy" people that insists, deep down, we're all a little nuts.
We've come to expect perfection from Pixar, mostly because Pixar expects perfection from itself.
Superbad has raunchy charm, a fair amount of heart and a couple of nice performances.
The Bourne Ultimatum leaps, scampers, scraps and drives its way into the pantheon of all-time great action movies.
For Mr. Boyle, a Swiss Army knife of a filmmaker, there's always something new.
You didn't think The Simpsons would sprain its funny bone on the way to the multiplex did you?

Talk to Me is more than enough fun as a showcase for Mr. Cheadle's wit and spontaneity and as an inside look at the airwaves' transition from warm and fuzzy comforter to the anything-goes entertainment of today.
Raise your hand if you've had any Kafka-like health insurance dilemmas. Yes, that's a lot of hands. And as it turns out, at least one has been severed.
He [Winterbottom] approaches his subjects as very, very real, not just fodder for topical films.

Evan Almighty combines the easiest elements of lazy comedy with the most indulgent elements of lazy disaster movies. Even Mr. Carell, gamely mugging and wincing and snaring the random reflex laugh, gets pulled down with the ship.
Dan Klores' crazy relationship doc Crazy Love takes a tale tailor-made for sensationalist treatment and sculpts it into a riveting three-act drama.
Why put so much sheen on a movie that warrants and provokes nothing more than mild diversion? It's like serving sloppy joes on fine china.
Independence is a subject Mr. Burnett knows well. After all, he was indie well before the term entered the film vocabulary. And it all started with the sheep killer with sad, distant eyes.
It's a very simple movie that ends up making room for some invitingly complex ideas.

Stripped of just about all artifice and dazzle, shot on the cheap on city streets, this Sundance gem is wiser about artistic creation and the fickle ways of love than any song-and-dance spectacular you've recently encountered.
At World's End has some fun stuff. If only it weren't so stuffed to the gills with moving parts.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Disposable, clever and never willing to pass up a chance to show how hip it can be, Shrek the Third should make kids titter, adolescents snicker and cash registers ring.
The transitional gears never grind. They just keep clicking until you know you're along for the entire ride.
It's hard not to admire the film's confidence in making the story its own, and Ms. Linney, a mix of iron will and emotional fragility, delivers her usual complex performance.
Terse, economical and infused with a low-fi feel that leaves its mark on everything from the film's light levels (low) to its music (mournful yet rocking), it's a sequel that surpasses the original.
The combat showstoppers, though still too CG to be felt as much as they're admired, should thrill fanboys to no end.
Hot Fuzz is the funniest send-up of slam-bang action mayhem since Team America: World Police.
It keeps moving forward, even if you're not always sure where it's taking you.
300 is about as subtle as a spear through the head. But it's also shamelessly entertaining, and not a bad way to make time move a little faster.
Black Snake Moan is thick with Tennessee sweat and grit and the sound of insects. And it takes an overwrought, steamy path to what at least feels like a moral cautionary tale.
Set, appropriately, in 1984, The Lives of Others weaves a compelling human drama into a chilling portrait of polite totalitarianism.

This isn't one of those labyrinthine works of deception that doubles back on itself at every turn. Breach is content to tell a strong story with the utmost efficiency and let its cast do the heavy lifting.
3:10 to Yuma manages to incorporate the rhythms of a contemporary action movie while maintaining a healthy respect for the tenets of the genre. That makes it a train well worth catching.
If Flags of Our Fathers is about heroism -- why we need it, how we create it -- then Letters From Iwo Jima is about honor, its importance, and its folly.
The film's genius performance belongs to the venerable Armin Mueller-Stahl, who plays the family head with a twinkling eye and an air of avuncular, Old World charm.
The Kingdom has its cake, eats it, then blows it up with an RPG.
The fourth chapter of the Indiana Jones chronicles feels repetitive and a little gassed, but it has too much bravura filmmaking, and just enough wit, to not recommend.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A superhero debut with brains and brawn.
Street Kings is the cinematic equivalent of solid crime-genre fiction. It keeps the visual pages turning for a couple hours and navigates the dark corners of corruption and dishonor among men.
It's always exciting when a film that plays with cinematic language can squeeze in among the flotsam and jetsam of repetitive mediocrity.

Funny thing about tragedy: It loses its heft when it has to keep reminding us how tragic it is. It's hard to cozy up to a script that feels the need to toss in casual references to fate and Aristotle. Yo, we get it already. They're doomed.
A remarkably economical, street-level view of widespread panic caused by an abomination that gets, and ultimately needs, no explanation.
Bucket's rush to sentiment leads you to think the film, not its characters, is soon to expire.

A haunting enigma that refuses to conform to any recognizable pattern, period or otherwise. I suppose you could see it as a descendent of Citizen Kane. But such comparisons aren't really fair to either film.
With Antwone Fisher and now The Great Debaters, Mr. Washington has made a pair of movies that dodge enough clichés to indulge in a few.
Mr. Hanks comes through with an egoless performance -- no movie star is so adept at not acting like a movie star -- and Mr. Hoffman continues his year of doing no wrong

I admire the intent of Mr. Smith, who has made it his mission to mix escapist fare with socially relevant material. Legend seems to split the difference and land in the middle of nowhere. That's a lonely place for moviegoers to be.
Atonement does what a tragic romance is supposed to do.
I'm Not There would make a fine exercise for graduate school analysis. I'm just not sure how well it works as a movie.
Enchanted isn't just a culture-clash fable, it's also a throwback to one of classic Hollywood's giddiest genres: the screwball comedy.
You feel Before the Devil Knows You're Dead more than you watch it. And the feeling is far from warm and fuzzy.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I can't speak for the standard-issue version, but the souped-up extravaganza is one of those experiences that remind you of the magic that movies are capable of conjuring.
The Coens are geniuses at creating tension through editing. No Country has craft and atmosphere aplenty.
The film's charm, quickness and design carry the day.
Ridley Scott packs the film with period detail and vivid, violent energy reminiscent of high-grade Scorsese, then mixes in a Lumet-like, keenly observed outrage at systemic corruption.

Dan in Real Life is an enjoyable if curious creature, a naturalistic ensemble comedy wed to a high-flown sitcom premise. It's infused with a warm optimism that prevails even through the drama's thornier patches.
A supple and angular story of grief.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: For all of the roiling emotion, it feels oddly flat, distant and one-dimensional.

The Golden Age feels like two movies: one a bodice-ripping romance, the other a study in statecraft and power. But these strands, one private, one public, come together in the title character and the balancing act she must master.
This is a 160-minute art Western, and if you're up for such a beast it is a glory to behold. It's gorgeous, but rarely for the sake of mere gorgeousness, and languorous, but never listless.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If Michael Clayton's particular mix of law and commerce gets a little murky, that murkiness also gives the film a shadowy aura.
In the Valley of Elah is an endorsement of doubt, a demand for questioning, wrapped in a package anyone can buy.
You mess with the Zohan at the risk of your own IQ. But anyone who realizes or cares about such hazards has likely crossed the movie off the to-see list already.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Ms. Dench is scary good, a collection of withering glances and quiet delusion accentuated by a wickedly funny voice-over. Ms. Blanchett matches her step for step.
The story is strong enough, but it's the atmosphere, thick with matter-of-fact doom and guerrilla warfare, that gives the film its quickened pulse.
The films strain to present some kind of moral compass, a philosophy of revenge's human toll. But in the end, their sadistic glee in creative bloodshed trumps all.
It's a masterful and unsentimental child's-eye view of the cold, hard adult world.
Writer and director Patrick Creadon makes us care about this passionate cast and finds visually inventive ways to illustrate the players' thought processes.
Dan's transformation hits the kinds of snags that might occur in real life but spell doom for narrative momentum.

Nacho Libre is more lazy than offensive. Things happen, but there's really no story. People do stuff, but they don't become characters. It might have made a dandy Saturday Night Live skit. But it's not much of a movie.
Even with its feisty, anti-corporate sympathies, this movie adaptation of Garrison Keillor's beloved Midwestern radio drollery is a breezy affair.
No other outfit can match Pixar's knack for plucking heartstrings without tearing them off the frets.

An Inconvenient Truth, like its star, is quite persuasive in framing global warming as a crisis rapidly accelerating along with the planet's population. That means us. And that means the potential to take action.
Mix in a whole lot of automatic gunfire, an overblown crime plot, a heavy dose of industrial-strength techno and a dystopian view of French social policy. Stir. Enjoy.
The spectacles linger in the imagination, but the rest is pretty easy to forget.
[Cornish] creates a character who pulls us in and makes us recoil all at once.
It's a feel-good movie that happens to dress in drag.
Visually energetic and light on its feet, it's frothy entertainment that has some ideas in its head and a sense of playfulness that turns those ideas into a speedily pleasant 90 minutes.
Simply runs out of things to do once it establishes its ground rules of defining stereotypes and mocking pretension.
United 93 is an exhausting but commanding work of art.
Too long by about a half hour, very much in love with its own excessive style, it still manages to be kinda creepy, at least when it stops taking its metaphysics too seriously.
An inspired piece of work by someone who knows and admires Mr. Johnston but doesn't cover up the warts. It's also the rare documentary possessed with an artistry that transcends its subject.
Manages to work as a subtle send-up of '50s film sensibilities and as a tentative study of an earlier sex symbol.
Brick drops down like a frenzied teen fever dream of criminal patter and hairpin plot turns. A word to the wise: Pay attention, or you'll feel a lot less wise.
Unlikely to win many new converts, but its core audience should have a rockin' good time.
Deceptively simple, stripped to the bare necessities, it quietly dramatizes the consequences of lying, cheating and stealing in a way that takes your intelligence for granted.

Henri Decaë's black-and-white cinematography brings out the melancholy mystery of Paris' boulevards and cafes, and Ms. Moreau, shot with natural lighting and without make-up, is like a mournful goddess of glamour.
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'échafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: A fun, smart film. But you can't help but wish Thank You would bare its fangs a little more.
Even when Meltdown melts down, it's still fun to look at.
Art with a capital A. Don't be afraid. OK, be a little afraid.
Serrill, making his feature debut, didn't plan on spending seven years with the Roughriders. But reality just kept getting more compelling and complicated, and his persistence paid off.
It's not a great movie, but at-risk teens could do a lot worse.
Much like someone who doesn't realize how high he is, A Scanner Darkly talks too much and doesn't say enough.
Two lessons learned: Dump a superheroine at your own risk. And animatronic sharks sure have come a long way since the days of Jaws.

It works, as homage to a particular time and place in film history, and as a knowing revision that brings Hollywood's subtext of '40s postwar corruption to the surface. The Good German isn't so much an imitation as a crafty modernization.

Told with a visual efficiency that belies the film's considerable length, Shepherd is a muscular, unsentimental movie about shadow warriors and dark compromises. It takes its audience's intelligence for granted and rewards it at every turn.
The History Boys is best when it crackles with the passion of ideas about the function and importance of ... ideas.
For all the film's beauty and mythic grandeur, it's the fetishistic fascination with gore that stays in your head and distracts from almost everything else the movie tries to do.
Always engaging, rarely revelatory, Bobby earns credit for its convictions and its ability to dramatize those convictions in the context of a man who embodied them.
The tone isn't as cute or vapid as most installments; it's actually a little sinister compared with any recent Bond.
Yes, Stranger Than Fiction is a head trip. But it's a very friendly one, and well crafted at that.
Individually, the stories are beautifully shot, intimately acted and usually engrossing.
In the words of the man himself, Borat is Big Success.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Sadly, the movie version is a dull-edged instrument that struggles to conjure the book's piercing internal voice.
Flags of Our Fathers is as handsome and gutsy as we want all our soldiers to be. That they can't always live up to our needs has more to do with us than with them.
What begins as a mischievous frolic gradually becomes a sad tale about a sad man.
Rude, crafty, funny and richly profane, it's the work of an artist unmistakably in his element.
A shrewd commentary on misguided Western excursions into the 'dark continent.'
This Film Is Not Yet Rated may be a mischievous, slanted and even angry piece of work, but it articulates a rage that filmmakers and film consumers have felt for years.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [Gondry's] passion for cinematic invention is giddy and palpable, with the rudimentary charms of fellow Frenchman and turn-of-the-century filmmaker Georges Melies.
An unnerving little psychological study that makes the most of the high-def aesthetic.

It may be the 9/11 movie to which the most people can relate. For most of us, that date wasn't about personal heroics or losing loved ones or survival. It was about processing the impossible and realizing that life, with all its ups and downs, must go on.
Despite some visual sparkle and musical razzle-dazzle, Idlewild is a messy movie.
In the aptly titled Conan O'Brien Can't Stop, we witness a performance addict with something to prove.
The Illusionist works magic and illusion with romantic panache.
What the movie lacks in visionary skill it makes up for in charm and wistfulness about the depleting effects of gentrification.
Unlike so many films that force life lessons down your throat, Little Miss Sunshine weaves them into the fabric of the story.

Talladega Nights is an unapologetic goof fest, light as aluminum and seemingly edited with Scotch tape. But it's smart enough to buy gags in bulk and puts them in the hands of three guys who can improvise until the cars come home.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Ant Bully is fun to look at, and Lucas' recognition of the strength in numbers leads to solid character growth.
A painstaking study in courage and conviction under agonizing pressure.

Mr. Shyamalan is plagued by a bad case of Robin Williams Syndrome, characterized by a desire to inspire and change the world through mediocre entertainment â" in this case, accompanied by ample and frequently creative bloodshed.

Snakes is bad in a bland, calculated, marketing-is-all way, which is what you might expect from a movie that has been shaped around its marketing campaign from the jump (or from the slither, if you will).
Juvenile. Strained. This baggy tale of a loopy Deepak Chopra wannabe is all that and then some. The thing is it's also pretty funny as long as you know what you're in for.
It's not exactly full of holiday cheer. Then again, perseverance can inspire and enlighten any time of the year.
Little Fockers packs in all the cynicism and laziness of a tired franchise's third chapter. It's the drive-through version of comfort food, comedy by repetition and indigestion.

If Laura Ingalls Wilder took a detour through Cormac McCarthy country on the way to her Little House, she might stumble upon True Grit, a classic Western tale livened up by a few Coen brothers tweaks.
With its rich source material shaped from real-life events, The King's Speech doesn't need to overplay its hand -- especially not with a king waiting in the hole.
This is polished entertainment with a little edge, a juicy urban fable for grown-ups.
The Tourist merely asks you to sit back and enjoy the ride, and then makes that task a breeze.
It finds the humor in an unlikely love story, and it resists any temptation to play it straight.
It's the kind of nightmare melodrama that rouses the best from director Darren Aronofsky, of a piece with his dark spirals Requiem for a Dream and The Wrestler.
Don't go to Boxing Gym expecting pugilistic melodrama about long-shot underdogs. There's not an ounce of fat or cliché in Frederick Wiseman's new documentary.
The latest from Danny Boyle is actually an ode to survival, a bracing story of man and nature and an exhilarating sensory experience. It's my favorite movie so far this year.
A Hollywood movie doesn't need to serve as media criticism. But don't serve yesterday's news, pretend to treat it as vital and then turn it into a mere bauble.

Whether it's parsing the definition of a derivative or detailing the bad faith of major financial institutions, the new documentary Inside Job approaches its deconstruction of the financial meltdown with laserlike focus.
A remarkable new documentary that reminds us of film's inherent capacity for lying.
Due Date is a modern change-up on the old screwball comedy formula.
It's about literature itself, the ways in which it works on the reader and the folly of applying some objective standard of decency and meaning to words on a page.
It relishes its myth-making enterprise without getting too cute about it.

A finely constructed feel-good movie, gorgeous to look at, suspenseful when it's supposed to be and firmly in control of the sports movie archetypes and tropes that it wields like an experienced jockey using a riding crop.
This one's a keeper.
Somehow the results come together like the perfect status update.

Waiting for 'Superman' won't satisfy anyone looking for a five-point plan. (It won't win many fans among teachers' unions, either.) On the other hand, if it's effective filmmaking you're after, look no further.
A mildly intriguing exercise in guerrilla filmmaking, lapsed ethics and the potential for social-networking deception.

The Town doesn't reinvent the wheel. It just does what it does with great conviction and a sky-high level of execution. It also forges ahead with one of the best Hollywood second-act stories in recent memory.
Quote not available.
This is Serious Clooney, starring in a deliberative film that could have sprung from mid-'60s France or Italy.
Animal Kingdom is a lean, patient crime thriller about one kid's transition from prey to predator.
Quote not available.
Breathless jumps to its own rhythm and pokes holes in its idols even as it worships them.
There's simply no center here, no sense that someone is guiding the ship.
Another marvel of perfectly drawn, fully realized characters created from the ground up and brought to aching and glorious life.

It moves well for the most part, it delivers a worthy bad guy, and, in Edward Norton, it has a hero constantly on edge and on the run, a more swaggering and modern version of Bill Bixby's Banner from the '70s TV series.
We're more concerned with the mock-shock screenplay futilely in search of a story, and the characters that could have been created on an Etch A Sketch.
"Write what you know," the standard advice goes, and filmmaker Mike Mills (Thumbsucker ) knew he had a compelling family story to tell.
One can pinpoint the exact moment when 13 Assassins transforms from vivid samurai drama to insane work of genius.
Woody Allen's beleaguered heroes have never been reluctant to indulge in a little fantasy to get what they want.
An audacious visual poet known for gently probing life's big questions, Malick has gone to the source of it all. He's gifted enough to bring out the spiritual dimensions of astrophysics.
The X-Men franchise always had a lot on its mind compared to most of its superhero brethren.
Rage has no expiration date in Incendies, director Denis Villeneuve's gripping, era-jumping drama about a family melded to its war-torn past.
Dead Man's Chest and At World's End meandered so far off course, and took so long to get there, that almost any Act 4 encore would qualify as a quantum leap forward.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Bridesmaids has a couple of X chromosomes up its sleeve, and you're wrong if you think that's merely a cosmetic difference.
It shouldn't seem as novel as it does.
You won't be the only one anticipating a car-crash appeal in The Beaver , that eerie sensation of not being able to look away from catastrophe.
Nothing against the buff, blond God of Thunder, but Thor just doesn't have a built-in wow factor among the nongeek brigade.
Every great album has its own creation myth.
movie_title: The Promise: The Making of Darkness on the Edge of Town (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In a Better World, Denmark's Oscar winner for best foreign-language film, boasts the kind of patiently constructed narrative that keeps you leaning forward and marveling at how all the pieces connect.
Equally at home chronicling the latest fashions on the street and the biggest celebrations among Manhattan's aristocratic swell set, he might as well be the city that forms his vast canvas.
Through three films, writer-director (and occasional actor) Tom McCarthy has navigated a tricky line between winsome and melancholy.
Think of Paul as a love letter to fanboys, especially the variety that knows the standards well enough to hoot along every time a sci-fi hit rings up a reference.
Like an angry tenant bent on revenge, the movie industry has depicted the destruction of Los Angeles with staggering consistency if not a wealth of imagination.
Give the genially bawdy '80s nostalgia trip Take Me Home Tonight credit where it's due: It's got the music part down pat
Guys can be desperately pathetic creatures when it comes to the opposite sex.
Like a slightly twisted, modern-day Frank Capra fable...
Paul Giamatti can do spunky (Cinderella Man) and stately (John Adams), but he's at his best turning potentially loathsome men into sympathetic characters that command your attention.
The Illusionistis magical in more ways than one.
Boasts quality of acting and an overall intensity level that make up for a lot of narrative shortcomings.
You can see where No Strings Attached is heading before it gets there, but it's still a pleasant enough and surprisingly romantic ride.
Roberts is the obvious focus here, but she's enough of a pro to get out of the way and let a scene be stolen.
The combination of social anguish and dark chill in Never Let Me Go packs a quietly devastating punch.
This is a meat-and-potatoes espionage yarn that passes by quickly enough and meets the requirement of making us try to guess: Who is Salt?
Celebrated French filmmaker Claire Denis is a master of atmosphere and immersion.
This is a distractingly busy movie, so in love with its own considerable craft that it can't stay still long enough for anything to settle in.
When it's all done we're left with another recent Gilliam trademark: the highly imaginative mess.
As long as Almodovar keeps investing such thought and energy in his work, he can play with whatever themes he desires.
They may not be Jack Lemmon and Billy Wilder , but Will Ferrell and Adam McKay have a pretty good thing going.
The Beaches of Agnes is a work of delightful contradictions from a filmmaker who has always played by her own rules.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Light on its feet, confident and modern, it's the work of a company hungry for respect and eager to remind moviegoers of its enchanting roots.
Few recent films have been so adroit at looking outward while burrowing inward.

What's a recovering ninja assassin to do? Why, paint the screen bright red, of course. Splatter it on. We're talking streaks and rivers of blood -- bloody swords, bloody clothes and, my personal favorite, bloody stumps.

The real star of this show is director Lee Daniels. He's the one who conjures the film's eerie mix of kitchen-sink realism and gothic symbolism, its deft back-and-forth between the horrific and the sublime.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A Christmas Carol is a worthy stab at mixing old and new, a vintage tale done with some fresh dazzle and a reminder that the movies can still bring the wow.
t gives a glimmering surface sheen to the glamorous mirage of David's high life and all but asks, "Would you make a better choice?"
A finely constructed and fiercely entertaining soccer movie that deals more in pride and obsession than penalty kicks.
It doggedly refuses easy ways out, and it has the guts, brains and critical eye to plumb the roots of terror and its bloody consequences.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: More Than a Game is more than a feature-length profile of LeBron James, and that's good news.
You know those comedies that hit a little dry spell and have a hard time recovering? Couples Retreat has one that lasts about, oh, 90 minutes.
It suggests that in a world gone mad, even the good guys can be a little cracked, and that, in an age of self-indulgence, it might be hard for a whistleblower to heed his own alarms.
Oswalt nails Paul's mix of sadness and devotion, and Siegel gives the whole affair an air of gloom with just the barest hint of satire.
The multigenerational threesome gathers in a spacious but cluttered studio to swap riffs, war stories, tips and inspirations.
Let's start with the praise because there won't be much: As comedy pairings go, you could do a lot worse than Jack Black and Michael Cera.
Away We Go pleads so earnestly for emotional resonance that it forgets to earn any.
The Dark Knight is easily the most entertaining bummer of the summer.
It's a fly-on-the-wall look at eight prodigiously talented kids hooking up to play ball in the big city, and as such, it's a great deal of fun.
Part of the joke lies in seeing a megawatt star embrace his inner grouch with fantastical blunders, and part of the anticipation lies in seeing Hancock become, well, Will Smith.
Dangerously close to the sublime, a film that will be dissected and enjoyed for years to come.
Consider The Wolfman a pedigreed genre yarn, mindful of its precedents but nimble enough to have a good time in the here and now.
This is among Scorsese's many gifts: Even when he's not crafting a masterpiece, he reminds you that the movies possess visceral and uncanny powers.
For Streep, as always, acting is anything but complicated.

[Depp's] wide eyes and high whimsy feel a bit derivative of his Willy Wonka (another collaboration with Burton), but he invests so much of his ample energy and instinct in these roles that it's hard to complain.
A comedy of modern manners with the texture of a great short story.
I found myself admiring the movie's stubborn adherence to its own universe and logic.
There's a fine line between gleeful anarchy and wasted energy, and Despicable Me has a wonderful knack for staking out its spot and staying on the right side.
A masterpiece of sparseness.
Ever been around a group of friends who crack each other up while you stand to the side and scratch your head?
Cop Out is like a parody of a parody of a parody, so derivative and desperate in its pleas for laughter that it's hard to tell when it's making fun of itself and when it has simply run out of ideas.
The technical wizardry only enhances Toy Story 3's emotional resonance.
A little bit of Russell Brand can go a long way, but Greek is a fine vehicle for his mock rock-god persona.
Nicole Holofcener is frequently lauded for writing vivid female characters, but such praise doesn't really do justice to her full game.
MacGruber manages to move beyond sketch comedy dimensions, but at 99 minutes, it's still a reach.
The entire film is stocked with images that reflect a character and story in flux.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Like Banksy's best street work, it pushes and prods our gullibility buttons and sends the mind swirling with questions of artistic authenticity and intent.
Cruise and Diaz are both easy to look at and they work well together.
The jump scares, given a little extra oomph by the ever-looming possibility of a double wake-up, do what they're supposed to do. They make you jump.
An urgent piece of work.
Not better but pretty good nonetheless.
A Prophet solidifies director Jacques Audiard's standing as a criminal mastermind whose work leaves genre classifications in the dust.
I can think of far less pleasant ways to pass 100 minutes -- many of them playing now at a theater near you.
This is a hugely ambitious piece of work that packs a cumulative wallop when it's all over.
Don't try to teach me about life in a movie called Hot Tub Time Machine. Stick to the sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll. It's your destiny.
This Clash of the Titans isn't bad. It's just not particularly necessary.

The film has the courage of its genre convictions. It doesn't have even a whiff of market testing. It does everything on its own terms, and in this age of McMansion movies, that's a super accomplishment.
For those who know the story, Most Dangerous Man puts it in fresh perspective. If you don't, there's probably not a better way to discover it.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It may not be your thing, but Sweetgrass is unlike anything you'll see in a theater this year. It bravely strays from the flock.
It's no big surprise that Lopez can still get laughs; she has a relaxed way with the camera that has mellowed and ripened over the years.

The only worthwhile character is bad guy J.P. (Joel David Moore), a gaming prodigy with a Gollum-like multiple-personality disorder... J.P. suggests a subtle, unconscious awareness of how stupid the whole movie is.
An incoherent and surprisingly underwhelming display, Alice Through the Looking Glass will probably make a fortune at the box office, but it'll leave a sour taste in your mouth.
Lest we forget, the original was grand. By comparison, this rickety and hilariously misjudged effort looks like one of those migraine-inducing, adventure-themed promo clips you'd skip on YouTube.
Alas, In the Heart of the Sea is certainly ambitious, but it never quite reaches its full potential.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A mesmerising tale of hope, survival and (if we're going to get all fancy about it) the sheer resilience of the human spirit.

There are plenty of 'inspirational' speeches and cloying montages, but no real depth or drama. It's also a tad offensive in its handling of the subject of euthanasia and, um, let's be honest, some of the dialogue is unintentionally hilarious.
The magic of Linklater's detailed, conversational piece... is in the performances (brilliant and, occasionally, affectionate) and the dialogue (sharp and endlessly witty).
Wonderfully acted and featuring a deeply unsettling score, Eggers builds his story meticulously, presenting an eerie, slow-burning sense of dread that, eventually, gives way to a distressing finale.
The Jungle Book is kinda awesome.
Bloated and hilariously self-indulgent.

The Force Awakens is, truly, a stunning exercise in large-scale filmmaking; a beautifully-assembled picture in which Abrams combines a magnificent cast with a marvelous flair for big-screen, sci-fi storytelling.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Truly horrid.
Bloody and violent in all the right places and outrageously funny/filthy in all the wrong ones, too.
A true story, no matter how fascinating it proves to be, doesn't always ensure a memorable picture.
Listen, it could have been a lot worse.
The plot is surprisingly short on laughs and over-reliant on relentless celebrity cameos.

Creed stands tall as one of the most entertaining sports films we've seen in years; a scintillating and, occasionally, moving piece with genuine heart, energy, depth and humour. Oh, and the fight scenes are brilliant.
Farrell and Weisz spark off of one another, delivering a convincing and rather touching on-screen partnership.
Game Night -- a slick, inventive and surprisingly efficient action/comedy -- is as solid a studio chuckle-fest as you could hope to see. Flawed, for sure, but we'll take it.

The meanest thing we could say about Greta Gerwig's Lady Bird is that there isn't enough of it. Maybe we're being greedy. Maybe 93 minutes is the perfect running time. That way, we can be sure we'll never tire of repeat viewings.
It's an unexpected joy, basically; a cosy and casual, Sunday afternoon offering, that passes the time nicely.

On the one hand, The Shape of Water plays out like a forgotten instalment of The Twilight Zone. On the other, it makes for an attractive date movie. Seriously, who'd have thought that something so bizarre could be so romantic?
It is an utter disaster; a staggeringly incompetent and woefully misjudged exercise.
A film that goes out of its way to avoid entertaining anyone with a pulse.
For 100 minutes or so, Bone Tomahawk plays out as a clever and truly enjoyable Western... and then the film turns all kinds of nasty.
There is a lot going on in here, but again, a confident Coogler takes a frighteningly tall tale and somehow manages to make a clean, thrilling and largely inventive sci-fi adventure out of it.

It is unashamedly sentimental, old-fashioned and bursting to the seams with Important Life Lessons. But it's very well put-together, indeed; a smart, effective and, occasionally, funny film that surprises at every turn.

Ruth Fitzmaurice's intimate account of a life devoted to her husband will move you to tears. This is a film about a filmmaker; a film about a man who continues to defy the odds - a film about living. Unmissable.
It is a hideous piece of work, basically; the kind of cheap and tactless blockbuster that you tend to forget about, even while watching it.
Kidman firmly re-establishes her reputation as a proper screen heavyweight.

Everything goes boom, crash, oomph, peow, wallop, zing, zat and zoom for 150 minutes. It's terrifying. It physically hurts. It is so darn-near incomprehensible, I almost asked for my money back. And I didn't even pay to see it.
So, um, that's it. Pirates 5 is grand. Better than expected. A serviceable sequel. Will there be another one? Dunno. Depends on how fast Johnny Depp spends his pay cheque.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The force is still strong with this one. It just takes the occasional wobble.
After Carpenter and De Palma, it may seem a little dated; yet Edwards' classical feel for pure cinema remains unalloyed.
In the realm of 'prophetic science fiction', it is a genre landmark.
Ulmer (Murnau's one time art director and assistant) is the most subterranean of all directors, and here turns out a triumph of mind, eye and talent.
Like all good documentaries, this is an enlightening insight into a previously unexplored world, to which the viewer feels privileged to have been introduced.
Like The Full Monty, this is sure to raise audience's spirits and leave them singing long after the credits roll.
Honest, poignant and occasionally very, very witty.
A minor, offbeat achievement, yet particularly impresses with its strong central performances from a masterly Holm and a sensitive Hjelje.
An energizing, intoxicating documentary charting the rise of hip-hop culture in general and the art of scratching (or turntablism) in particular.
A love for films shines through each frame and the era is recreated with obvious affection, scored to perfection with some tasty boogaloo beats.
A farcical, partly autobiographical, and frequently hilarious comedy charting the adventures of an odd couple abroad.
Atanarjuat will make you laugh, make you cry and keep you on the edge of your seat for nearly three hours. Isn't that what cinema was supposed to do all along?
The increasingly diverse French director has created a film that one can honestly describe as looking, sounding and simply feeling like no other film in recent history.
Friel ... and Williams ... both create sympathetic and thoroughly believable individual characters.
As a portrait of the complexities facing a young Jewish Nazi, this is compelling stuff.
An elegant, awfully English affair -- an atmospheric country-house whodunit with a stellar cast and crew from the UK.
Rifkin's references are ... impeccable throughout.
Distinctly low on laughs and, despite a running time of only 86 minutes, far outstays its welcome.
This is a difficult film to watch and near impossible to rate.
movie_title: Raw Deal: A Question of Consent (2001)

movie_review_blurb: An ambitious feature with some original touches.
An intriguing debut.
The most remarkable feature of Lukas Moodysson's film is how convincingly the director gets under the skin of each of his characters.
An extraordinary and imaginative examination of human nature.
Strives toward originality but all too often falls back on jarring clichés.
A piece of unashamedly traditional filmmaking, which relies upon solid plot and strong characterization as opposed to more experimental shock value.
Far from the film that you would expect it to be considering the talent involved.
A compelling tale of obsession and addiction.
What at first seems to be a rather insubstantial romantic comedy gains an impressive amount of verve and variety as it unfolds.
A smart and original character study that presents real truths the viewer can recognize.
A humane and surprisingly comic feature.
An emotionally devastating study of adultery.
An astonishingly rich and multi-layered film that is possibly the director's finest to date.
Successfully subverts traditional representations of the undead.
Gillian Anderson is a revelation as the tragic Lily Bart.
A frank and startling feature that is hard to stomach but harder still to forget.
For the most part a lot of fun, with some fine performances from a mature cast.
A delightful feature that is as charming as its title and as beautiful as its Venetian setting.
Shot in black and white, Marc Singer's compassionate film introduces the audience to the tunnel's many inhabitants.
The film becomes overcrowded with its irreverent touches and eccentric interludes, which increasingly feel strained and awkward.
Such quirky characters and humorous observations give this slight diversion plenty of precious moments.
Kapadia constantly proves himself to be a director with not only an astonishingly rich visual imagination but also a strong sense of narrative, intelligently integrating a handful of flashbacks.
Hero's thrilling mixture of the audacious and the exquisite offers the viewer a myriad of treats.
This crowd-pleasing tale of growing pains is a work of undeniable charm and unexpected gravity, endowed with an offbeat sense of humor that will appeal to fans of Jim Jarmusch and Aki Kaurismaki.
An uneven oddity.
