Dwayne Johnson's Race to Witch Mountain plays out like a kiddie franchise starter kit.
Surrogates - double the sci-fi fun in only 85 minutes. Why the rush, Mr. Willis?
Frozen proves you don't need serial killers or supernatural shocks to keep us entertained. Man vs. Mother Nature will suffice.
The Invention of Lying gleefully deconstructs the standard rom-com, but it hasn't a prayer as an anti-religious screed.
Stick a fork in M. Night Shyamalan. He's done as a director of consequence after The Last Airbender. Sad.
Poor acting, lousy special effects and theatrics better suited for an Afterschool Special. Yup, Twilight is back.
Who needs things like narrative cohesion and logic when you've got Cruise and Diaz at their winsome best in Knight and Day?
There's a Director's Cut version of Jonah Hex, right? Because this film feels like a series of bullet points disguised as a feature film.
Can we put Pixar in charge of every movie sequel?
The new Karate Kid changes the scenery - and targeted demographic - but it's still a thrill to see the bully take his medicine.
Dumb, noisy and relentlessly violent ... did you expect anything different?
Splice teases us with greatness before settling in as a messy, but never dull, sci-fi thriller
Get Him to the Greek is a worthy companion piece to the underrated 'Forgetting Sarah Marshall'
Why resist the obvious? Prince of Persia is genetically engineered to make money - and sequels.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Edgar Allan Poe would be intrigued - if not outright proud - of Tell Tale
Let Shrek Forever After be the final Shrek chapter so the franchise can end on a reasonably high note.
Roland Emmerich had to be behind Tidal Wave, right?
Brooks spoofs the master, Alfred Hithcock, and make a minor comedy classic of his own with High Anxiety
Brooks' fractured History is salvaged by the tuneful 'Inquisition.'
The Good, the Bad, the Weird - When Tarantino met Leone ... and Spielberg, too.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Don't blame the Bard for Letters to Juliet
Screen royalty elevates Just Wright from the rom-com heap.
Cheer up, Robin Hood, you're a screen icon, for crying out loud.
If Iron Man 2 had any more subplots they'd call it Iron Man 2-5
While the film can't measure up to its psychologically bent scenario, it's still an intriguing choice at the local DVD store or on-demand service.
Harry Brown proves you're never too old to take out the trash.
Lbs. tackles a common problem with uncommon dignity.
You may not agree with the solutions offered in The Cartel but it's impossible not to be outraged at the corruption on display.
New Freddy, no new scares in this tepid reboot of the Nightmare on Elm Street franchise.
The title only hints at the horrors within this deeply disturbing - and thoroughly original - shocker.
Who needs 3-D? The Blu-ray Avatar jumps off the small screen until the director's clunky moralizing takes over.
Despicable Me is Gru'd enough until the next Pixar smash arrives in theaters.
The B-movie pleasures found in Predators make the original look like high art.
The Sorcerer's Apprentice conjures plenty of FX but too little magic.
This micro-indie has a full-sized heart and enough humor to make its scale immaterial
Can't we all just coexist? The Infidel can't bring the laughs, but it's a subtle peek at scapegoating on all sides.
You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger gives another gaggle of actors the chance to boast they made a Woody Allen movie - just not a very good one.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Explosions! Sight gags! A bald, bombastic Bruce Willis! But Helen Mirren steals Red every time she opens fire.
It's Kind of a Funny Story proves Zach Galifianakis is more than just a bearded clown - but he needs to seek out better scripts.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Note to Hollywood: If a movie like Life As We Know It needs diaper gags to make us laugh, you're in trouble.
Let Me In actually improves on the source material without resorting to the pathetic tics of most American horror films.
The Social Network boasts enough great dialogue to fuel a half dozen Oscar-bait movies.
The couple at the heart of Monsters is so insufferable you'll be cheering on the aliens.
Never Let Me Go settles for the worst of two genres - the dreary arthouse film and the sci-fi feature.
John Rabe preserves history while painting a portrait of a most complicated hero.
Teen comedies like Easy A invoke the John Hughes canon at their own peril
All is forgiven, Ben. Just stay behind the camera so you can give us more films like The Town
Hip hop hoax or artist reborn? It's hard to care after suffering through I'm Still Here
The Back-Up Plan saves itself - and us - by abandoning its farcical gimmick mid-film.
Centurion is like 'Gladiator' directed by Freddy Krueger
Takers is all flash, no substance. But for two-thirds of the film that style - and the always gritty Matt Dillon - is more than enough.
The Last Exorcism takes the best elements from 'The Exorcist' and 'The Blair Witch Project,' but the ending is scary for all the wrong reasons.
Making a great B movie requires more than just fake blood and breasts, something the minds behind Piranha 3D already know.
The Switch proves Jason Bateman should headline more features - and that we don't need another sperm donor comedy.
The leads in this beautifully told drama are more than just all right - they're Oscar worthy.
Scott Pilgrim vs. the World or its alternate title, "Dude, Where's My Attention Span?"
The Expendables scratches the itch action fans have had since the '80s drew to a close.
Hope & Crosby. Abbott & Costello. Laurel & Hardy. Ferrell & Wahlberg won't be joining this select group if The Other Guys is any indication.
Duvall is Duvall, which is all the reason you need to check out the sly and charming Get Low
With apologies to Vin Scelsa, Dinner for Schmucks is an idiot's delight
Bass Ackwards proves the road trip film is alive, well and in very good hands
Wartime will make you squirm just like Todd Solondz's other movies. But it still marks a departure for the king of alienating cinema.
Inception is a nightmare for audiences looking for coherent fiction.
No shaky cam! No logic-defying stunts! But The American also lacks a pulse.
No one expected 'Part 2' to rival the original, but it delivers a fair number of scares while replicating the eerie tension from the first film.
Kick-Ass gives the superhero genre a jolt, but you'll feel queasy rooting on an 11-year-old killing machine.
Date Night is worth hiring a sitter to see ... but only for the Fey/Carell connection.
If The Final Destination is what horror fans want these days, be very, very afraid.
The DVD release of Vampire Killers leaves out the 'Lesbians' from the title. Also missing are funny jokes, thrills and engaging characters.
It's Complicated proves Nancy Meyers has the aging rom-com genre to herself - and it's in very good hands.
Carey Mulligan deserves serious Oscar consideration for her work in An Education.
Clooney, Reitman both soar with the richly satisfying Up in the Air
Director Clint Eastwood turns a remarkable true story into an unremarkable film with Invictus
Brothers isn't your standard PTSD yarn.
The word 'brave' is thrown around too liberally in Hollywood. The folks behind Burma VJ are the bravest souls you'll see on screen this year.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: My Sister's Keeper demands nothing less than a tidal wave of tears.
Fantastic Mr. Fox proves there's still life in the stop-motion format - and in Wes Anderson's droll approach to movie making.
Precious is the first film of 2009 that cannot be missed.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Saint John of Las Vegas marches in lockstep with virtually every cliche of the modern independent film.
Hollywood nearly ruins a great true story like The Blind Side by piling on the schmaltz.
Daybreakers injects just enough fresh blood into the vampire genre to make it worth your while.
New Moon nearly convinces non 'Twilight' fans to embrace the teen franchise, but the final half hour is a stake through the film's heart.
The debacle that was Troll 2 has given birth to Best Worst Movie, easily the most enjoyable documentary you'll see all year.
2012 director Roland Emmerich never met a landmark he didn't want to crush with a digitized fireball, boulder or avalanche.
Up delivers a half hour of pure cinematic magic, followed by the rest of the film which is merely very good.
Anvil! goes all the way to 11.
Truth is stranger than fiction, and The Fourth Kind is neither strange nor fictional. It's just plain silly.
The only major change Disney's A Christmas Carol takes with the source material is draining the humanity right out of it.
We've seen much of The Canyon before, but the crisp execution transforms the film into more than just a boilerplate thriller.
Even a two time Oscar winner like Hilary Swank can't make Amelia soar like it should.
A Serious Man may be intellectually provocative, but the signature Coens brother tics are all but suffocating this time 'round.
Where the Wild Things Are is too quirky for the kids and too scattered for grown ups, but boy does it come close to capturing the book's eternal appeal.
Law Abiding Citizen doesn't follow the laws of logic, let alone competent storytelling.
Paranormal Activity lives up to a good three quarters of the hype. That's a better equation than most of today's limp horror hits can boast.
The former swingers settle for standard gags in the moderately amusing Couples Retreat
Is Anybody There? devolves into a predictable yarn about a boy and a grandfatherly figure - but adding Michael Caine to the mix means it's still worth your while.
Rule no. 34 - movies like Zombieland give the undead a very good name.
The Book of Eli gives us some of that old time religion - along with a heaping helping of violence.
Extraordinary Measures battles to overcome the 'disease of the week' tag - and eventually succeeds.
Andy Garcia, comedy cutup? City Island gives the intense actor a fine comic showcase.
Your enjoyment of Clash of the Titans is aided by remembering the original was one big ol' hunk of cheese, too.
Sherlock Holmes is neither a cookie-cutter blockbuster nor insulting to the source material.
The Collector won't join the pantheon of horror movie monsters - unless somebody lowers the bar down to the ground.
Hot Tub Time Machine is 'The Hangover' lite. Very lite.
If Jennifer Aniston and Gerard Butler are indeed a real-life couple, The Bounty Hunter may be designed to keep the paparazzi off their trail
Repo Men starts with a sly premise - and then adds literally nothing of worth thereafter.
Remember Me is a far more accurate barometer of Robert Pattinson's acting chops than that teen vampire franchise.
This Alice is more Ripley, or Lara Croft, than timeless story heroine.
The Ghost Writer could be a disappointing career capper should the wheels of justice finally start rolling.
Brooklyn's Finest is an entertaining rehash of every cop movie cliche committed to celluloid.
Southwest Airlines officials might be the only ones laughing at Kevin Smith's Cop Out
The Crazies is the sharp, sophisticated horror remake we've been waiting for.
The Spy Next Door is bland, unassuming stuff for the kiddies. But few family films have Jackie Chan at their disposal.
Shutter Island pays homage to film noir thrillers without giving us any new thrills.
Triangle is so shrewdly conceived that you won't mind its mentally draining resolution.
There's never a silver bullet around when you need to put a lame monster reboot out of its misery.
A galaxy of stars can't make us fall for Valentine's Day, but it sure can keep us distracted for two hours.
And the winner is ... Sean Penn for Milk
From Paris with Love is a Royale with way too much cheese for most diets.
44 Inch Chest puts the spectrum of the male ego on brutally efficient display.
When in Rome needs every ounce of its leads' twinkly appeal to keep us engaged.
If Edge of Darkness exists simply to get Mel Gibson back on the big screen ... so be it.
You might disagree with every point made during Collapse but it's unnerving all the same.
If Jeff Bridges earns an overdue Oscar for Crazy Heart it won't be for any charitable reasons. It's arguably the best performance of his career.
Clive Owen turns a tear-jerker into a meditation on fatherhood in The Boys Are Back
Into Temptation treats Catholocism - and its audience - with a great deal of respect.
Maybe it's time for Dwayne Johnson to back to his action movie roots ...
Adam is a sweet, unconventional love story nearly derailed by a far too obvious subplot.
Australia isn't "Titanic 2.0," but neither is it "Heaven's Gate.
Mamma Mia! is a sloppy, overwrought mess of a musical, but then those darn ABBA songs pop up and all is bliss for the next three minutes.
Twilight is the ideal vampire movie for teen girls -- and nobody else.
Bewitched casts a spell with its show-within-a-show plot, but ultimately fizzles with its flat romance
The Honeymooners is as unnecessary a remake as one might fear, but we've seen plenty of worse TV to film translations
Madagascar will unite parents and their tykes with laughter
Don't blame Hilton for this misbegotten Wax job
This Kingdom would truly rule with a Crowe or Gibson, not a middleweight like Orlando Bloom
This Horror is slick, supernatural and stale
The mindless Sahara is smart enough to keep the action and wisecracks at a fevered clip.
It's hard to fathom a more faithful comic to movie transfer than the gloriously violent Sin City
Shouldn't Queen Latifah be able to find better projects than an unnecessary spinoff like Beauty Shop?
Guess Who doesn't play the race card nearly enough
The Upside here is the brilliant work of Joan Allen and Kevin Costner. Yes, that Kevin Costner.
This soggy sequel to The Ring proves you can't go to the well more than once
Robots displays a tin ear for endearing characters and storytelling
Vin Diesel makes a shaky foray into kiddie films with The Pacifier
Constantine provides a novel twist on the typical comic book movie until it collapses under its own goofy logic
Hitch wastes both Will Smith and Kevin James with yet another convoluted romantic fable
Alone in the Dark doesn't even deserve the indignity of going straight-to-video
Fascination should make a bee line to Cinemax's late night lineup, where it belongs
This cop remake is an Assault on the cast's respective resumes
Ice Cube's Are We There Yet? strands the genial rapper in Home Alone-style high jinks
Quaid and Grace are Good Company, indeed
Garner's moxie can't lift Elektra above its sluggish storytelling
The Woodsman proves any topic, even pedophilia, can be tackled onscreen if handled as expertly as it is here.
Spanglish translates into an overly earnest dramedy from a filmmaker who should know better
Daggers is a jaw-dropping spectacle that outclasses 'Crouching Tiger'
"Song" broke ground for minorities, not for filmmaking
This big-screen SpongeBob won't win over many new fans
Land of the Dead is second-rate Romero, which means it's far better than most horror films being made today
The new Fantastic Four might have been palatable if we hadn't already met a certain wall crawler or Caped Crusader on screen.
Charlie hits the sweet spot despite Johnny Depp's misguided take on the Wonka legend
The Island boasts a neat sci-fi story, but director Michael Bay can't help but blow that up, too
Bee Movie is a light, moderately entertaining romp. Not that there's anything wrong with that.
Teeth bites off more than it can chew.
Audiences will identify more with Sydney White's misfit cast than its bland leading lady.
Ira & Abby may drive you into therapy, but you'll be chuckling all the way.
Rocket Science brings the squirm-inducing comedy genre to new heights
The Invasion saps all the spirit out of what once was a classic alien saga.
Rambo shows Stallone ran out of ideas after penning 2006's Rocky Balboa.
This Rush job should put the franchise down for good.
If 3:10 to Yuma can't resuscitate the western, nothing will.
The Kingdom unapologetically shows U.S. agents knocking off terrorists.
Fred Claus won't make us forget "Rudolph," "Frosty" or even "The Santa Clause."
American Gangster delivers fine drama, gripping performances and a dizzy morality tale. But it should have been oh, so much better.
This Compass points to the end of a would-be franchise.
Seed of Chucky doesn't even rise to the straight-to-video standards of shlock horror
Shut out the massive hype, admittedly easier said than done, and Cloverfield is a terrific monster movie for our age.
I Am Legend has everything a great summer blockbuster should have - except it's hitting theaters in December, not June.
Director Rob Reiner continues his creative free fall with this flawed, one-note List.
Zathura could have used that Tim Burton touch, but it's still an imaginative way for kids to kill an afternoon.
Derailed could send Miss Aniston's film career off the rails
Two for the Money lets Pacino be Pacino, only one of the film's weak links
In Her Shoes tries in vain to shed its chick-lit roots
The funny, adventurous Serenity proves there is life after cancellation.
Into the Blue does the impossible - it makes a film featuring a bikini-clad Jessica Alba as dull as a bag of sand
Pretty Persuasion thinks it's smarter than everyone in the audience. It's not.
Red Eye packs all the tension of a turbulent flight but ends with the equivalent of a stale sack of pretzels
Singleton's style over substance approach is the right way to tell Four Brothers' vengeful story
Stealth offers the kind of razzle dazzle action Michael Bay only thinks he creates.
Hustle & Flow shows even pimps believe in the American Dream
The musical biopic gets a much-needed smackdown in the fitfully hilarious Walk Hard
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: P.S. offers two plum roles for stars Laura Linney and Topher Grace and at least three plots for them to unravel
Saw is all gristle and no meaty scares
Sideways cements Alexander Payne's status as one of our best directors
This Day is truly a disaster, just not the kind the studio had in mind
Stateside veers toward "Showgirls"-level camp but merely ends up being awful.
Breakin' transcends cliches thanks to Jamie Foxx's irreverence and charm
The Olsens go the Britney route in this unfortunate Minute
Van Helsing desecrates the memory of our greatest movie monsters
This Attraction is one besotted, befuddled affair
The Punisher shouldn't be this silly even for a comic book film brought to life.
Vol. 2 finally tells us why we should care why Bill gets killed in the first place.
This Girl's split personality dooms this coming-of-age yarn
Walking Tall's one-note vigilante action won't serve The Rock's star ambitions.
Redemption eludes DMX's antihero in the soulless Never Die Alone
Scooby-Doo 2 improves on the original, but that's not saying very much at all
Grim, gory Dead proves a capable, if not superior, remake of the 1978 original.
Saved finds salvation in not skewering its target with too much venom
Depp's Window turns a typical King yarn into a rewarding psychological portrait
Broken Lizard's Club Dread spoofs a genre already spoofed out, the slasher film, and does it badly
Havana Nights makes us long for the days when Patrick Swayze lived on Hollywood's A-list
Hackman wins in a landslide in the otherwise mediocre Mooseport
This Eurotrip should be reserved for desperate video store selection only
Dates proves once more Sandler and Barrymore can trump the silliest shtick
Served crackles with energy during its dance sequences. Eventually, the hoofing stops and so does the movie.
Caine makes Statement rise above its soporific story.
This Date goes better than we had any right to expect.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The implausible Torque is for those who found The Fast and the Furious too urbane
This Baby deserves a spanking.
Liberty's engaging leads make this pedestrian romp a harmless way to spend two hours
The Cooler gambles on a gritty love story and comes up a winner.
Paranormal Activity 2 should have been a quick, cynical cash in on the original. Instead, it's a chiller that stands tall on its own.
Mortensen's charisma can't tame Hidalgo's runaway plot
Cassandra's Dream is second-rate Allen, but it's still compelling thanks to its magnetic co-stars.
Chronicles packs too much story into what should be another Diesel shoot 'em up
Sap is sap, but The Notebook's cast renders the dual love stories worthy of our affections
Team America puts Michael Moore and company to shame by being fair and balanced in its comic assault on the left and right.
Listen to Taxi carefully and you can hear Jimmy Fallon's film career stalling.
Lights will make leave you cheering long after you digest its unflattering portrait of small-town obsession.
Ladder 49 nearly burns itself by adoring its subject matter too much.
This Tale has been told before, but we don't mind hearing it again
The Forgotten delivers enough chills and thrills to make us forget its flaws
The Last Shot delivers cinematic nuggies to Tinsel Town
Wimbledon is like a tennis match played with wet balls and wooden racquets - soggy and stiff.
Mac hits a stand-up double with Mr. 3000, his first major leading role
Resident Evil: Apocalypse is for those who found "28 Days Later" too brainy.
Don't hang up on Cellular - the silly setup gives way to an oft-thrilling adventure.
Snicker Park is more like it
Can a movie be lighter than helium? Danny Deckchair proves that conclusively
Napoleon Dynamite is like a cinematic bully, picking on the nerds with apparent glee
Let's hope Exorcist: The Beginning marks the end of a franchise that never should have gone beyond the 1973 original
AVP equals PU
Yu-Gi ouch! Rare is the movie experience as painful as it is here
This otherwise limp Book injects a neat wrinkle into the chick film formula
Harold and Kumar give brain-dead comedies a good name
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Shyamalan's Village provides an open window into his gifts - and flaws - as a top-flight director
This Catwoman's super power is dressing up Halle Berry in a sexy leather number and still leaving audiences snoozing.
The true Giants are the colorful, old-school surfers who give this documentary its heart
I, Robot is everything a summer blockbuster should be
Anchorman may be uneven, but Will Ferrell's Ron Burgundy is a character worth revisiting
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The characters in this Sleepover should be grounded
Before Sunset is all talk, and audiences will be listening intently to every word of this smart romance
Spider-Man 2 is double the romance and one half the slam-bang action
These Chicks should be, like, totally stood up
Cheeky trio keeps Without a Paddle afloat - barely
Transporter 3 delivers precisely the same thrills as the first two installments. Take that as a warning - or an invitation.
Denzel delivers both in front of and behind the camera with The Great Debaters.
Shoot 'em Up dispenses with plot, character development and coherency, but it's a blast all the same.
Death Race drips with cheese, and it's insanely proud of it.
The House Bunny gets its hop from the terrific Anna Faris.
Transsiberian shows there's plenty of life left in the 'strangers on a train' genre.
The Clone Wars may introduce a younger generation to the franchise - while chasing away existing "Star Wars" fans.
The anti-PC Tropic Thunder will have audiences laughing too hard for any offense to be taken
Bottle Shock is like a discount bottle of wine you'll savor despite its apparent flaws.
You'd have to be high to think Pineapple Express is anything but a letdown.
Doomsday might seem novel - if you've never seen "The Road Warrior," "Aliens," "Escape from New York" or any other post-apocalyptic flick before.
Be Kind Rewind should gather dust on both DVD and VHS shelves.
Step Brothers is like watching someone get kicked in the groin for 90 minutes, but it still makes us laugh.
Believe every ounce of the hype surrounding The Dark Knight.
Beyond the Gates takes an unflinching look at the start of the Rwandan genocide.
Severance finds inspiration where horror and comedy intersect.
Charlie Bartlett is the Ferris Bueller of our drug addled age. Except he's not a fraction of the charmer ol' Ferris was.
Fido finds a new wrinkle in the nearly exhausted zombie genre.
Meet Dave is a fish-out-of-water comedy with a rather annoying fish.
Hellboy II is a creature feature unlike any you've seen before. But next time, let's try a little storytelling, too.
My Blueberry Nights proves Norah Jones isn't ready for a movie career quite yet.
Hancock tries to reinvent the superhero movie - until it loses interest in its own story.
Vacancy is a no-nonsense, no ambition thriller, but sometimes that's more than enough to please.
Shutter features another pale, scraggly haired young woman a la The Ring haunting our protagonists. Yawn.
Bonneville gets by - barely - on the strength of its three leading ladies.
Triloquist sets the killer ventriloquist dummy genre back a decade.
WALL*E begins with all the comedic splendor of a Charlie Chaplin film, but quickly devolves into a rickety bore.
Get Smart has it all - the Cone of Silence, the shoe phone, the familiar one-liners. But the re-imagined Maxwell Smart isn't nearly as funny as the original.
Mike Myers channels his inner Benny Hill for the endlessly juvenile comedy The Love Guru
Hulk smash! But first Hulk apologize for Ang Lee movie of my life.
It's rare for today's movies to tackle terrorism as the deadly threat it is. It's even more uncommon to see Don Cheadle give a lackluster performance. Traitor serves up both.
The French thriller Tell No One shows Hollywood how to make a knotty mystery that's both logical and deeply satisfying.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Burn After Reading is typical Coen brothers, but Brad Pitt's appearance is anything but expected.
De Niro. Pacino. There's little other reason to watch Righteous Kill other than to see a missed opportunity.
Chocolate gives us the first autistic action hero.
Slumdog Millionaire is just the sort of rags-to-riches yarn that turns Academy voters' heads.
The Brothers Bloom distills elements from films by the Coen brothers and Wes Anderson down into a wholly original, and hilarious, caper.
The latest Bourne adventure lacks the clarity and vigor of the previous ... oh, wait, Quantum of Solace is a Bond movie?
Four people. One Kwik-E-Mart style shop. One crazed creature. Splinter proves that's all you need for a chilling horror movie.
Let the Right One In is not your typical boy meets vampire, boy falls in love with vampire saga.
Don't do as these naughty Role Models do, just laugh right along with them.
Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa repeats all the gags from the first film ... but lacks enough new material to warrant another rumble in the jungle.
Waterworld drowned in bad buzz during its theatrical release. It deserves a better fate.
If cop movie cliches are a crime against cinema, Pride and Glory should be under arrest.
What Just Happened is second-rate satire but a first-rate example that De Niro can still be great on screen.
The Dukes sings in a low-key harmony that's hard to resist.
Pacino can't be accused of sleepwalking through Christopher Nolan's brilliant Insomnia.
Two regular Joes square off in The Promotion, a sly comedy that finds fresh humor in the workplace.
RocknRolla is pure Guy Ritchie. All style and not even a pretense of substance.
What's a smart, well-crafted horror movie like Quarantine doing in today's marketplace?
W. is just as shallow, poorly conceived and biased as advertised.
The hero in Red doesn't want revenge. He wants an apology. This isn't your ordinary vigilante film.
An American Carol dares to mock the Left, but it forgets to bring the funny.
Changeling is a pretty good Lifetime Original Movie. But it's a far cry from Clint Eastwood's best films.
Body of Lies is smart, sophisticated and hopelessly uninvolving.
Religulous reaffirms Maher's wit, but it also sheds light on his penchant for moral equivalence.
Mother of Tears puts a dent in Argento's rep as a horror maestro.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Eagle Eye requires blind faith in its silly storyline
Surprise, surprise. Lakeview Terrace is smarter than its B-movie plot suggests.
Ghost Town relies on Ricky Gervais' ability to play a rather mean lead character - until suddenly it doesn't.
Kabluey nearly implodes in the opening moments but swiftly finds its footing.
The chorus members in Young@Heart don't trash hotel rooms or bed groupies. But they also aren't going gently into that good night.
Zack and Miri gives the rom-com genre a much deserved spanking.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: M. Night Shyamalan has morphed from "the next Spielberg" to a punching bag for critics and audiences alike. The Happening reminds us why.
Bigger, Stronger, Faster* tackles the steroids debate in ways audiences won't see coming.
You Don't Mess with the Zohan is the best Adam Sandler comedy in ages - but for only the film's first 20 minutes.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Caine's performance in Flawless is just that. As for his co-star, Demi Moore ...
Run Fat Boy Run wouldn't make it to the finish line without Simon Pegg's winning performance.
Does Alien vs. Predator: Requiem spell the end of the dual-monster franchise? Let's hope so
Walk the Line isn't as great a biopic as Ray, but it's still a fine tribute to the Man in Black and his muse.
Meet the Browns deserves its box office glory, Madea's clunky cameo notwithstanding.
Drillbit Taylor is second-rate Apatow, but it still outperforms most teen comedies.
Funny Games is like a graduate thesis on screen violence. It's less successful as a compelling piece of cinema.
Fine performances - including a nasty turn by Dennis Hopper - rouse Sleepwalking from its slumber.
Outlaw commits an unforgivable offense. It makes the vigilante genre boring.
10,000 B.C. takes a prehistoric approach to storytelling.
Miss Pettigrew recalls the screwball comedy era, but it's more a stylish simulation than a full-bodied feature.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Things We Lost in the Fire sounds like a made-for-Lifetime weeper. But two superlative performances means "Fire" is anything but a by-the-book drama.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Ferrell can't jump in the tepid Semi-Pro
21 is based on a true story. So why does so little of this blackjack drama ring true?
Penelope is a fairy tale that will leave parents just as engrossed as their kiddies.
This Funeral won't leave audiences in a mournful state.
30 Days of Night reinvents the vampire movie, but only with its novel premise.
It hardly matters that The Signal is deeply flawed. This one has cult favorite stamped all over it.
No matter how you look at it, Vantage Point is a letdown.
We Own the Night declaws the organized crime genre.
George A. Romero's Diary of the Dead goes light on the fright but heavy on the polemics.
Jumper teleports straight to the 'Worst of '08' list.
Definitely, Maybe is certainly the most ambitious, and satisfying, rom-com in recent memory. That's faint praise given the recent run of romantic fare.
Just because The Spiderwick Chronicles isn't an insta-classic doesn't mean it's not a fine time at the movies.
Great World of Sound is a corrosive antidote to "American Idol."
Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show succeeds when it focuses in on the comedian's homes off the range.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: You'll be glad you spent time In Bruges
Feast of Love will fill you up with trite dialogue and sappy plot contrivances.
Wes Anderson's latest may be Limited, but even the director's lesser projects are worth our while.
This Sentence is as grisly and violent as the trailer portends.
Married Life gives new meaning to the phrase, "'til death do us part."
Leatherheads proves you can't make 'em like they used to, no matter how hard someone like George Clooney tries.
Kung Fu Panda gets a big kick from the vocal trio of Jack Black, Dustin Hoffman and Ian McShane.
Sex and the City can't live up to the HBO series, but simply having the foursome together again will be more than enough for hardcore fans.
Road to Victory tackles sexual dysfunction with a delicacy that belies its gridiron backdrop.
Helen Hunt stars in, directed and co-wrote Then She Found Me, and she handles each chore beautifully.
Indiana Jones offers solid summer entertainment, but where's the laughter, romance and soul that made the original trilogy so memorable?
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian dials down the spirituality but cranks the level of action to 11.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Visitor might unite both sides of the illegal immigration debate - at least for two hours.
Hilary Swank may have two Oscars, but P.S. I Love You proves she has plenty to learn about romantic comedies.
The supporting players save What Happens in Vegas from rom-com infamy.
Speed Racer provides an exhilirating, albeit exhausting, ride through our pop culture past.
Made of Honor takes zero liberties with the rom-com formula, but the delightful Michelle Monaghan makes walking down this aisle a treat.
Iron Man forges a new trail subsequent superhero films would be wise to follow.
The Orphanage proves the haunted house genre is alive and well - in the right hands.
Priceless smartly updates the selfish pluck that powered Breakfast at Tiffany's more than four decades ago.
Rogue is the best killer crocodile movie - ever.

Is Katherine Heigl the new Meg Ryan? The fitfully entertaining 27 Dresses suggests just that.
The Savages proves there's a rich vein of humor to be mined from the darkest of themes.
Lars and the Real Girl proves love is blind - and it can be inanimate as well.

Let's start up a collection so Al Pacino doesn't feel the need to take paycheck movies like 88 Minutes
Flawless beauty aside, Miss Alba never seems like the Everywoman she needs to be in order for Honey to click.

The Grand gambles on its cast's improv chops but comes up only with a pair of sevens.
Street Kings wastes a better than expected turn by Keanu Reeves. That means he never says the word 'dude' or breaks into a mean air guitar riff.
Smart People serves up everything you'd want in a shrewd indie picture but is strangely inert.
We all knew Johnny Depp could act. The brilliantly imagined Sweeney Todd shows he can sing, too.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Jodie Foster returns to her kiddie film roots with the warm and whimsical Nim's Island
Harold & Kumar should be thrown in Gitmo for starring in such an awful sequel.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sam Rockwell turns Conviction into his latest "For Your Consideration" ad.
Turning, 'Ugh, another remake' into, 'hey, I wouldn't mind a Pete's Dragon 2
Jim Carrey plays to both his comic fan base and those who want to see him stretch that limber frame with I Love You Phillip Morris
Yes, War Dogs indulges in the expected Bush bashing. It also has a message about the anti-war crowd. And it isn't kind.
Can we edit out all the extraneous lecturing and make Hell or High Water a four star movie? Please?
Yes, of course Meryl Streep is excellent as an infamously awful opera singer. It's Hugh Grant who continually surprises in this slight but charming comedy.
Come for more F-bombs than a season of "Deadwood." Stay for the aggressive religion bashing!
What starts as that rare big screen role worthy of Joel Kinnaman takes a depressing turn.
Don't Think Twice is hard to watch at times ... but that's a compliment!
Can't we go back to watching those cool Suicide Squad trailers and ignore this massive disappointment?
Matt Damon should have listened to Matt Damon about the folly of making a fourth 'Bourne' adventure.
Into the Forest offers that rare take on a dystopian future. So why is it so often a slog?
At the rate western culture is declining, Can We Take a Joke? may soon be dismissed as "hate speech.
Just try not talking back to the screen during Lights Out. We dare you.
Stop all the CGI action pieces! We just wanna watch Spock and Bones bicker.
Ghostbusters is the remake our culture richly deserves.
The Infiltrator is so good you'll think you're watching a TV show.
Four funny, engaging stars adrift in a sea of strained sexual gags.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Here's one for the poster: Legend of Tarzan isn't as misguided as 'The Lone Ranger.' Not even close!
If Election Year had depicted Muslims like it does Christians there would be picket lines greeting every theater showing the movie.
The BFG brings Roald Dahl's beloved book to ffafja'afnnnn... sorry, dozed off (like I wanted to do during the film).

Matthew McConaughey is so virtuous in Free State of Jones he can even make adultery seem really cool!
Guess what else the fascinating Weiner exposes, above and beyond those salacious tweets?
The guy who once 'acted' by raising a single eyebrow can now steal scenes from Kevin Hart.
It's a gentle, life-affirming love story interrupted by some nasty demons.

Presto! Change-o! You just lost two hours of your precious time.
Justin Bieber, please go to your nearest safe space. Immediately.
Maybe it's time for the franchise to take a knee.
The movie magic engulfing Kubo starts with the rich stop-motion animation. That's just the beginning.
Ben-Hur lacks the grandeur, the majesty of the 1959 epic. It's still a gripping story with a chariot race that lives up to the expectations.

This would be one heavy slog without its luminous leads.

You'll admire Arrival far more than you'll love it.
Can the "wizards" behind those DC Comics movies please take notes while watching Doctor Strange?
It's not jump out of your chair scary or a laugh riot. Yet Another Evil is a deft horror-comedy all the same.
When was the last time a movie romance gave you a lump in your throat? Here ya go!
At a time when even 'accountants' kick butt, we need a thinking man's hero like Robert Langdon more than ever.
I'm Not Ashamed is spiritual to the core, and there's nary a sermon in sight.

If this is truly the Battle of the Sexes circa 2016 we're doomed.
Desierto delivers white-knuckle thrills AND an ugly attack on those who want a secure southern border.
Mr. Affleck, we can't get you on the Batman set yet. Would you settle for a 'Bourne'-type movie about an accountant on the Autism spectrum? No, we're not joking...
These satires work best when the actors show at least a morsel of sympathy for their targets. With Mascots condescension reigns supreme.
Noisy, soulless and utterly lacking in magic ... this Alice has it all!
Emily Blunt is fabulous before the story embraces its inner 'Gone Girl.'
The Birth of a Nation might be the most faith-friendly movie you'll see all year, although it won't be promoted that way.

movie_review_blurb: Chris Pratt is better off playing in his own 'Galaxy' than starring in an oater.

movie_title: Is That a Gun in Your Pocket? (2016)

MSNBC ... the Movie!

We waited 15 years for this??

movie_review_blurb: The far-left lead character in The Names of Love is so enchanting even Rush Limbaugh would give her the time of day.
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In Time needs a few more rewrites before it can knock on the door of great sci-fi films like 'Blade Runner.'
The hangover from The Rum Diary doesn't hit until the uninspired third act.
The visionary behind 'Star Wars' could learn a thing or two from the smart, and richly comic, documentary The People vs. George Lucas
The new 'Activity' is dumb, strained and obvious. But you'll be scared all the same, and nothing else matters.
Hugh Jackman refuses to let audiences leave Real Steel without being entertained, no matter how silly matters get.
Why did Contagion have to be such an antiseptic thriller?
In space, no one can hear you scream ... but you'll hear plenty of giggling in the final moments of Apollo 18
Smart, thrilling and morally complex ... not much more you can ask of The Debt
Beware of nattily dressed strangers knocking at your door ...
Horror fans can look past a whole lot of stupidity in their favorite genre. But Don't Be Afraid of the Dark simply asks too much of us.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If you're gonna make an unnecessary remake like Conan the Barbarian at least keep it breezy, an approach director Marcus Nispel wisely heeds here.
A few cool 3D effects are the only improvement Fright Night offers over the campy original.
Slacker comedies don't get much lazier than 30 Minutes or Less
The Change-Up thinks any ol' R-rated gag will make us howl.
Consider Rise of the Planet of the Apes a belated apology for Tim Burton's misbegotten 2001 remake.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "Alien" had great characters, unrivaled shocks and a claustrophobic atmosphere. Prometheus ... looks great!
Rites of Spring fuses two durable movie genres together, but neither supplies the requisite chills we demand.
Nolan's final Batman film delivers grand excitement, grounded performances and the kind of conservative themes rarely embraced in blockbuster films.
No Arnold, no personality.
Stand Up Guys needs a Grumpy Old Men-ectomy, stat.
Schwarzenegger is older, and creakier, than we remember, but that's part of The Last Stand's folksy charm.

Robert Pattinson works mighty hard to make Cosmopolis more than just an erudite slap at modern capitalism. The Twilight heartthrob ultimately fails to rescue a meandering story hitting stale versions of the same talking points.
Sleep Tight threatens to be a real snooze until the film's electric second half jolts us awake.
Hit & Run may stall early and often, but the Bell/Shepard screen chemistry serves as a nitrous boost.
Zero Dark Thirty is a model of artistic restraint, a film letting fantastic history trump the need to score partisan points.
Not Fade Away is the greenest film of the new year, recycling '60s cliches with alacrity.
Arbitrage avoids lazy, anti-corporate talking points to tell the thrilling story of a man drowning in his own greed.
Promised Land wears its ideology on its sleeve, along with its hackneyed plot twists and wholly unbelievable characters.
Peter Jackson catches a nasty case of George Lucas-itis with his latest Middle earth saga.
Santa slasher flick sticks to genre template while Jaime King works overtime to make us care about the person gunning for ol' St. Nick.
Butter is a dizzying blend of smug satire, surface-level observations and mean-spirited swipes at flyover types. Oh, and take away Olivia Wilde and it's a laugh-free affair.
Come for the bear scene ... stay for a survival saga worth all of Leo's suffering.
When Harry Tries to Marry shakes up the stale rom-com formula.
The villain isn't intent on destroying the world, and the gadgets consist of items you might find at The Sharper Image. The 23rd Bond outing delivers thrills all the same.
Fanny, Annie & Danny will make you run up and hug your sketchiest uncle this holiday season. Family dysfunction at its finest.
Here Comes the Boom lets Kevin James strip off his shirt as well as his reliance on pratfall comedy.
Ben Affleck, director, can do no wrong with the terrific political thriller Argo. Ben Affleck, actor and star, that's another story.
The Giant Mechanical Man has the heart of a smart, sophisticated indie rom-com with wacky supporting players swiped from your average Kate Hudson clunker.
"Gran Torino" felt like a fitting end to Clint Eastwood's acting career. Turns out Trouble with the Curve is just as solid a send off.
Taken 2 shows there's just enough juice in this formula to fuel a solid sequel. Any more Mills family kidnappings, though, and things will quickly descend into farce.

Josh Lucas drinks, bats his watery eyes and stares into space for nearly 90 minutes in Hide Away. And yet somehow the actor overshadows the obvious life lessons that threaten to sink the project at every turn.
This zombie revolucion takes aim at our funny bone and the damage done by the Castro regime.
Wafer-thin characters aside, Premium Rush delivers thanks to Michael Shannon's unhinged villain.
The film's ending is a letdown, but it's a blast to root for such a brassy, rhymes with "itch" heroine.
As Yogi Berra might say, The Possession is deja vu all over again.

The Bourne Legacy is competently made, features a rugged hero and packs a few visceral wallops. It's also a wholly unnecessary extension of the "Bourne" brand, and that fact drags down the entire project.
Who doesn't hate it when critics say, "this is an important documentary you must see!" Well, Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry is a critically important documentary you need to see.
Seeking a Friend mocks the modern rom-com formula, but its apocalyptic gags soon give way to a heart-breaking love story.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The Awakening is a handsome, well-acted thriller with a script that's never cringe-inducing. So why did it sneak its way onto home video with no fanfare?
Crazy, Stupid, Love. is as chock full of great laugh lines as it is unnecessary punctuation.
Captain America's rousing first half proves Chris Evans was the right choice to play the Star Spangled hero.
Bereavement is one nasty piece of work.
The Farrelly brothers can only wring so many laughs out of excrement in Hall Pass
Birdemic defies traditional criticism. It's awful, but isn't that the point?
Vanishing on 7th Street feels like a classic in the making until we get to know the main characters.
Unknown hinges on an amnesia cliche so moth-eaten sitcoms long ago gave up on it.
Two delightful stars nudge Wild Target into sleeper territory - but only by a few inches.
Ed Helms finally gets a starring role to call his own in Cedar Rapids, but John C. Reilly swipes the movie out from under him.
Silly, soggy but certainly suspenseful, Sanctum is a B-movie pick-me-up.
Hoffman, the unofficial king of indie films, gets a bit too precious with his directorial debut.
The Mechanic threatens to deviate from the Statham Action Movie Template, but only for about 40 minutes.
Primal is neither original nor well polished, but it brings the gore like a respectable genre outing should.
Portman shows Heigl, Bell and Aniston what it takes to be a rom-com queen in No Strings Attached.
The Green Hornet attempts to mock its own genre, but it forgets to deliver a compelling characters along the way.
The only thing missing from this slight comedy of misunderstandings is Mr. Furley - and a scene set in the Regal Beagle.
Paltrow's got the pipes, but Garrett Hedlund steals Country Strong out from under her.
This Jack Black attack is just right for Gulliver's Travels, a kiddie flick with no discernible aspirations.
We didn't really need another True Grit, but the Coen brothers delivered a smart, funny retelling of the Rooster Cogburn saga all the same.
We now know 'Spanglish' wasn't a fluke. Writer/director Brooks' artistic decline continues with How Do You Know
Tron: Legacy validates those who spent the last 28 years defending the original film as a story worth telling.
Dawn Treader delivers some epic-sized adventure, but it simply isn't good enough to extend the franchise.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Natalie Portman fulfills the promise she hinted at in her pre-teen roles with Black Swan - even if the film itself is emotionally inert.
The Tourist is as beautiful as it is soulless.
Is The Next Three Days implausible? You betcha. Tell that to the magnetic stars, the smart screenplay and the impassioned direction by Paul Haggis.
A stop gap, not a movie.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Casting Billy Bob Thornton in Faster means it's more than just a generic action vehicle for the man once known as The Rock.
Denzel vs. a speeding locomotive - no contest.
Rachel McAdams proves perkier than a dozen Katie Courics in Morning Glory
Parents will be nudging aside their children to check out the thoroughly mature western known as Rango
Hollywood can always count on Philip K. Dick, whose short story inspired The Adjustment Bureau, to bring something fresh to tired film formulas.
What do you get when you cross 'Twilight' with a cherished children's story? Don't ask.
Battle: Los Angeles will delight your inner 8-year-old while your brain cells wither and die.
Deathly Hallows - Part 2 is everything a Potter fanatic could want in a franchise capper.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cher and Sly Stallone as a lion couple? Quirky voice casting helps Zookeeper rise above its kiddie film trappings - barely.
Horrible Bosses won't make you forget "Office Space," but you'll be laughing too much to mind.
Larry Crowne makes losing your job, your car and your house look like the greatest thing to happen to a middle aged man.
Dark of the Moon is just as loud, dumb and illogical as you expect. But when those neat 3D action sequences kick in, none of that matters.
Bad Teacher gets a shiny new apple thanks to a raunchy turn by Diaz
Cars 2 feels like a rival animation studio trying to copy the Pixar formula - and failing.
Jim Carrey shrewdly lets his tiny co-stars have most, but not all, the fun in Mr. Popper's Penguins
Green Lantern uses so much CGI it's a wonder anyone bothered bringing a camera to the set.
Monogamy asks us to root for lovers who seem disinterested in their own future.
J.J. Abrams' Super 8 can't live up to its advanced billing, but it's still a crisp combination of 'Goonies,' 'Stand By Me' and ... I can't spoil the rest.
The Hangover Part II feels like the fifth or sixth installment in the franchise. It's that out of fresh ideas.
The Beaver puts the focus back on Mel Gibson the actor, not the tabloid nightmare.
A more accurate title for Friends with Benefits would be Pretty People Trying Way Too Hard For Our Amusement.
On Stranger Tides is arrgh-uably the best franchise sequel yet. Faint praise, to be sure.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Bridemaids may make Kristen Wiig the first female'SNL' alum to ascend to the A-list.
Thor isn't 'The Dark Knight,' but it's a mighty fine kickoff to the summer movie season.
All together now ... if you loved the first four Furious films there's no reason on Earth why you won't dig Fast Five
No passion, no problem. Water for Elephants creates a wonderfully dark circus atmosphere to keep our interest when the film's love triangle falters.
Kudos to Atlas Shrugged for bringing Ayn Rand's iconic novel to the big screen at long last. Now, about that script ...
Scream 4 isn't the embarrassment one fears from such a belated return to a sleeping franchise. But it's neither scary nor inventive enough to warrant its existence.
The new, not so improved Arthur drinks less but still brings the funny.
With Source Code Duncan Jones proves he's sci-fi's most promising young director.
James Wan's Insidious is both an apology for the numbing 'Saw' sequels and proof old-school horror still rocks.
Zack Snyder's Sucker Punch should send shivers down the spines of Superman fans.
Fat, Sick & Nearly Dead makes it safe to eat your vegetables again.
The guilty must pay ... and pay in I Saw the Devil, an unrelenting Korean shocker.
Welcome back, Matthew McConaughey
Never mind 'Machete,' Hobo with a Shotgun is the real heir to the Grindhouse glory daze.
You know Melissa McCarthy has arrived in Hollywood when you see her receive mediocre material like Identity Thief and watch her make it funnier than it deserves to be.
Brad Pitt's hit man yarn keeps getting interrupted by political talking points as well as director Andrew Dominik's obsession with Tarantino-style tics.
At this stage in the franchise, the best thing to be said about the Die Hard sequels is that they come up with cool titles.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The great Joel Kinnaman tips the scales in our favor in the generic, but perfectly adequate, Run All Night.
Unfinished Business is strained, unnecessarily crude and downright bizarre in spots. Yet you'll laugh just enough at Team Vince Vaughn to forgive and (mostly) forget.
If Chappie director Neill Blomkamp's potential sinks any faster he'll be in M. Night Shyamalan territory before too long.
The man who made girls jump on trampolines delivers better rom-coms than the rest of Hollywood.
The effects hold up 20-plus years later. So do the thrills. Yes, 'Jurassic World' has its work cut out for it.
Tell your friends you saw the next comedy cult classic before anyone else ...
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Out of the Dark proves that quality acting and a fresh setting can't revive a DOA yarn.
Focus isn't one con too many. It's about a half dozen more than any story can handle.
Kevin Costner is suddenly the go-to star for tackling the country's thorniest problems on screen.
Coming of age yarns sink or swim based on their protagonist. The minds behind All the Wilderness chose well with Kodi Smit-McPhee.
Will you sign the necessary paperwork to enjoy Fifty Shades of Grey?
Style to spare? Sure. Bond-like flourishes? Yup. Yet Kingsman crumbles under the weight of its own ultra-violence.
Warner Bros. has this critic's approval to use my quote in Jupiter Ascending's ad campaign: 'It's not as gloriously awful as feared.'
Black or White is far from perfect, but it's an ideal way to kick off a healthy discussion on race in America.
It's amazing what a killer mask and a smarter than expected ending can do to a mediocrity like Smiley
How's this for the movie poster? Strange Magic isn't as awful as its trailer suggests...
Odd that we're applauding the fact that an actress can, you know, act, but here we are celebrating Cake all the same.
The Boy Next Door is two scenes short of becoming a camp classic. Maybe next time, J-Lo.
If your children say they don't want to see Paddington send them to their room sans supper.
Eddie Marsan almost makes the equivalent of watching paint dry invigorating in Still Life. Almost.
Blackhat boasts a ripped from the headlines theme and dialogue swiped from a dime-store novel.
Tropic Thunder pushes more buttons than most comedies dare.
Predestination feels familiar for the first 10 minutes, then it goes places we've never been before.
This Annie wouldn't survive on 'American Idol' or 'Dancing with the Stars.' She's a charmer all the same.
It's clear the Museum franchise is running on fumes. Tell that to Ben Stiller and Rebel Wilson.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Does anyone expect more than a frantic, action-packed finale that still can't measure up to any of the "Rings?"
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Here are the Top Five reasons Chris Rock's latest deserves little of the hype it's receiving.
They didn't turn Cinderella into an action heroine or reboot the story for our cynical age. And thank heavens for that...
It's better than 'Sharknado,' but that's not a good enough reason to give Zombeavers a try.
Is it too late to apologize to Jessica Alba and co. for their previous "Four" features?
Rogue Nation's opening scene is as thrilling as anything we've seen from those "Furious" films. And your brain won't hurt minutes later.
The Force Awakens reboots the franchise right ... so why does it feel like a 'Star Wars' remake more than a sequel?
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a good sign when you care more about the characters in the framing device than the guys fending off the whale attacks.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: We don't need another hero, right? American Hero begs to differ.
Bleeding Heart shows that all the asanas in the world can't change a man with hate in his heart.
Even Mother Teresa's harshest detractors might say she deserves a better biopic than The Letters
Welcome to MSNBC ... the movie!
Is Gene Jones the best late bloomer Hollywood has to offer? Dementia proves it.
Yo, Sly! You might wanna practice that Oscar speech, the one you originally wrote back in 1976.
Can a movie be family friendly while talking about a character drowning in blood?
Silverman's shtick may be getting tired, but her bravura turn in I Smile Back suggests a career resurgence.
Seth Rogen, the Pied Piper of pot movies, delivers just enough laughs for sober audiences to enjoy The Night Before.
Mockingjay Part 2 might be a wake up call for teens who think revolutions don't come with strings attached.
The third-act twists that sink Jackie Earle Haley's directorial debut are downright Criminal.
Penguins of Madagascar will make you weep with its short attention span pacing, but you'll be laughing too much to care.
A nefarious Bond villain apparently stole the Spectre script and reduced Oscar winner Christoph Waltz's role to a sad, super-sized cameo.
Bone Tomahawk shows the Western is more than sturdy enough to thrive in 2015.
Ever Oscar-bait element lines up for our approval. So why isn't Steve Jobs better?
Is Nick Nolte auditioning for the Burgess Meredith role in a "Grumpy Old Men" reboot?
Is it a comedy? A coming of age film? A cautionary tale? A romance? These Friends can't make up their minds.
Lousy ending. Weak anti-western culture jab. But the film's midsection is as tense as any movie you'll see this year. Or next.
It's fine for a no-expectation channel surf stop. Otherwise, let's put this quasi-franchise out of its misery.
Imagine how high Evel Knievel would have soared in our social media age?
Straight Outta Compton celebrates the gangsta rap era with a bit too much glee, but it's mesmerizing every step of the way.
It's a better catalog than movie, but Man from UNCLE offers enough panache to pacify ticket holders.
Some of the worst movies give way to the best documentaries...
movie_title: Lost Soul: The Doomed Journey of Richard Stanley's Island of Dr. Moreau (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Can a comedy be too funny for its own good?
For once the bad buzz and worse trailers were wrong. This hero deserves a movie all his own.
The Gift doesn't succumb to genre banalities until its final scenes. That's more than enough reason to see it.
Scare quotes around a movie title have never been so necessary.
Come for the comic chemistry between the leads ... but flee for moments that make you cringe for everyone involved in Horrible Bosses 2.
Project Almanac features that awful found footage gimmick, but don't let that stop you from meeting these charming, time travelin' teens.
It's not as snooze worthy as the first part of "Harry Potter's" finale, but that's the only good news out of Mockingjay Part One.
Prepare to have Dolphin Tale 2 shred your cynicism and feed it to the sharks.
Frontera avoids stepping on an illegal immigration soap box until the movie's final shot.
The Drop doesn't just offer James Gandolfini's last screen performance. It reminds us character-driven mob movies still matter.
It's like a Woody Allen movie--same music, same shtick--but without the uneasy moral takeaways.
The touching Heaven Is for Real marks faith-based filmmaking's next logical step into the mainstream.
The Winter Soldier will reaffirm your faith in big-budget moviemaking that can tell a politically balanced story.
If only more movies could slip social messages into their stories as deftly as A Hijacking does.
The Birth of the modern zombie film wasn't scary. It was downright hilarious, according to this smart new doc.
Dopey Pollyanna politics meet hackneyed storytelling. Elysium has it all!
An Occupy Wall Street supporter is part of the most conservative indie film you'll see all year. Still Mine is a heartbreaking classic no matter your ideology, though.
Lazy liberal talking points meet increasingly inept storytelling ... White House Down has it all!
Arrive with two aspirin and lowered expectations and the pounding in your head will be virtually nonexistent.
Little Hope Was Arson is far more than a small town detective yarn. It's a tribute to clear-eyed storytelling and the power of community.
Movies shouldn't always judge their protagonists, but a little judging might have helped The Last of Robin Hood.
Our Lindsay Lohan-obsessed culture gets its comeuppance in this surgically precise satire.
Iron Man 3 is a primer on how not to handle a superhero sequel--but Paltrow's abs look great!
Firth and Blunt give life (and flawless American accents) to this restrained, and occasionally bland, road trip flick.
The Company You Keep comes down hard on modern-day journalists but takes it easy on '60s era radicals bent on destruction.
42 hits too many obvious Biopic Moments, but Chadwick Boseman's Jackie Robinson is too busy swatting home runs to care.
Midway through The Host I started longing for the depth and sophistication of any random Twilight movie.
Admission offers two appealing leads, a gaggle of potentially strong themes and, well, that's about it.
Olympus Has Fallen isn't ashamed to wave the American flag, but it should be embarrassed of its cliche-ridden script.
No Toto, no problem.
If we must endure the unnecessary trend of rebooting kiddie stories, they might as well be as breezy and fun as Jack the Giant Slayer
Bless Me, Ultima creates a wholly original coming of age story by blending mysticism with conventional Catholicism.
Dwayne Johnson officially leaves his Rockness behind in the thoughtful, gritty Snitch
Lloyd Dobler and his pals at the Gas 'n Sip would have had a field day mocking a movie like The Factory.
Like found footage horror movies? You'll change your mind after enduring the British import Hollow
Come for the barrage of clunky plot devices but stay for the morally repugnant comparison between religious radical killers and capitalists.
Whitewash will have you rooting for a man who did a very, very bad thing.
Look past the 3D gaiety and candy-colored treats and, well, what is there, exactly?
The Maze Runner is clever, absorbing and good for both teens and parents -- until that silly reveal.
Willow Creek is the best found footage shocker in ages, a statement that speaks volumes about the floundering genre.
Stretch offers more narration than a Morgan Freeman film festival, one of several pot holes it jumps over without a ramp.
The Theory of Everything treats Stephen Hawking's intellectual accomplishments like rom-com filler.
Dumb and Dumber To traffics in politically incorrect jokes, the kind that tell you the Farrellys are stretching for filler, not testing boundaries.
Come for the charming Baymax ... but stay for the film's embrace of very 21st century cultural values.
It's almost impossible to resist recommending Interstellar, but it's equally tough to deny a galactic sense of disappointment.
The Taking of Deborah Logan or as it was originally called, 'How Found Footage Nearly Wrecked a Solid Horror Romp.'
Nightcrawler sends its media criticism out in ALL CAPS, bludgeoning Jake Gyllenhaal's excellent performance.
23 Blast has a tiny budget and an uninspired script, but the bond between the leads is worth cheering.
A four-alarm smug assault stops Birdman from being the classic it might have been.
Stonehearst Asylum will make you think twice about how we care for the mentally ill then ... and now. Oh, and it's also a smart thriller with a kiss of pulp.
A welcome celebration of Mexican lore isn't enough to bring this Book to Life.
Camp X-Ray seems more outraged by military sexism than the notion that Gitmo remains open in the Age of Obama.
Fury suggests U.S. soldiers can be just as savage as their enemies before remembering the Greatest Generation saved the world.
Fresh, original movies like The Mule come from the least likely places (if you've seen the film's trailer).
Bigfoot lives, but every other element in Exists is DOA.
Youthful cliches trump insight in Very Good Girls.
You'll ask, 'what was Denzel Washington thinking' more than once while watching the exploitative movie adaptation of The Equalizer
The Song starts like some of its clunkier faith-based predecessors. We soon learn it boasts both fine music and a sense of how temptation can rock even a strong marriage.
Witches, sight gags and a treatise on the battle of the sexes? Witching & Bitching gives you plenty to think about between the carnage.
Early favorite for most disappointing Oscar-bait film of 2014.
Ninety-plus minutes later, we're still waiting to see why this creepy doll deserves her own horror franchise.
Believe Me pokes fun at gullible Christians, but it has another, more deserving target in its sights.
Horns may bounce from fable to black comedy, but that erstwhile boy wizard keeps the focus where it belongs.
No doc could diminish George Takei's life work, but To Be Takei too often takes dramatic short cuts which undermines its potency.
Kill the Messenger is best enjoyed by taking the 'based on a true story' label loosely.
Can a bloated, cliched drama still serve as rousing entertainment? The Judge answer in the affirmative.
XMoor teases a new approach to horror, but the third act feels awfully familiar.
Stephen King's voice can be heard in the third act of A Good Marriage, but by then you won't care enough to listen.

[What] will hold your attention? The choppy, stitched music? The animation? It could've gathered its best components to make a tighter one-hour film; but as it stands right now, it can be a tedious chore to get through.
A spellbinding epic with great characters, visuals and pathos.
A powerhouse marriage of sight and sound.

In between bizarrely low-octane moments of authorities circling the ring, the soulful up-and-comer crafts a far more perilous tale, one of a teenage caretaker getting a crash course in growing up too fast, too soon.
The film should have taken a cue from its spice-loving subjects and jacked up the heat.
There's family-friendly fluff here, sure, but this dish has considerable bite.
What it lacks in cohesion, City of Gold makes up for in its subject's wit and wisdom.
Benson's efforts have turned Eleanor Rigby into an accessible, garden-variety love story, and that's its biggest problem.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: At times, there's a bit too much going on, and it starts to feel like maybe we're just being set up for Vol. 3. But so what if we are? Fun is the name of the game here, and Vol. 2 has it in spades
From Bridesmaids to Bad Moms, the whole "women behaving badly" schtick is certainly nothing new. But is it still funny? It can be -- when you've got leading ladies as good as the cast of Rough Night.
Will leave fans feeling like they've had some fun with old friends - just maybe not quite as much fun as they used to have.
Once again you'll find yourself cringing and laughing in equal measure. It's just not quite the killer comeback that Office fans might have expected.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A well-intentioned home invasion thriller that can't quite address all the issues it raises.
Curiously inert for such purportedly thrilling subject matter.
Open-hearted gushy romanticism in CinemaScope. What's not to love?
A disturbing, honest portrait of female neurosis and depression.
Thomas approaches the brutality of slave life with a pointedly elliptical style - allowing the audience to fill in the gaps.
There's an urgent impetus at the heart of this film, far beyond the realm of either flat period biopic or mere history lesson.
This cockeyed, oblique attempt to get closer to the worldview of David Lynch-one of American cinema's finest oddities-is a compelling slice of cinephile inquiry.
A compact thriller with real human consequences.
A vivid portrait of one of the most remarkable, pioneering women of Hollywood's Golden Age.
In this twitchy, claustrophobic view of moral degeneration, it becomes apparent that this town is not so much convulsed with guilt as with defensive anger.
The monsters are the highlight of the film, and if history is any guide, there will be more ghosts and evildoers for our wholesome heroes to battle in Scooby-Doo 3.
This film is so understated and restrained that even the bedroom scenes seem detached.

American Teen is stronger without calamitous characters, whose traumas might've overpowered the film, desensitizing the audience and leaving little room for the important nuances of love, conformity, friendship, heartbreak and yearning.
Quote not available.
It's not Shakespeare a la Kenneth Branagh, but it's not bad either.
Make no mistake -- this one is lowbrow comedy all the way.
Good news for you moms and dads out there who will undoubtedly be dragged by their kids to see this film -- it's actually quite good!
Hardly anything about this comedy is remotely funny, unless you get a kick out of Snoop Dogg getting stoned and dropping f-bombs every few words.
